lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 24 (Reuters) — Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from President Nguyen Van Thieu's radio speech today on the cease‐fire agreement:

headline: CONGRESS UNITED IN VOICING RELIEF
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23—Members of Congress, after years of bitter debate over the war in Vietnam, united tonight in voicing relief and gratitude that the conflict appeared to be at an end.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Kissinger and Tho End Talks With Handshakes and Smiles
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 23—Henry A, Kissinger and Le Duc Tho concluded their long negotiations on a Vietnam cease‐fire today with glowing smiles and hearty handshakes.

headline: Credit Markets in Stabilization; Treasury Issues Register Gains
lead_paragraph: The capital markets, aided by a report of diminished inflation during December and by expectations that President Nixon would announce a Vietnam ceasefire, showed signs of stabilizing following the sharp decline that set in with Phase 3.
author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr

headline: CONGRESS UNITED IN VOICING RELIEF
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23—Members of Congress, after years of bitter debate over the war in Vietnam, united tonight in voicing relief and gratitude that the conflict appeared to be at an end.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: BIG SWINGS MARK DOLLAR TRADING
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 23—The dollar moved down early today, depressed by a flow of money into Switzerland yesterday, then rose in the afternoon on rumors that a Vietnam peace agreement had just been signed in Paris.
author: By Clyde II Farnsworth Special to The New York Times

headline: HANOI SAID TO HINT AT SMALLER FORCE
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Jan. 23—A Canadian member of Parliament, just returned from North Vietnam, said today that officials there had told him that the projected international force that is to monitor a truce would be kept smaller than the United States had originally proposed.

headline: AMEX PRICES OFF DESPITE A RALLY
lead_paragraph: After falling sharply most of the day, prices on the American Stock Exchange recovered somewhat yesterday after the White House reported shortly before 2 P.M. that President Nixon would announce at 10 P.M. developments in the Vietnam War.
author: By James J. Nagle

headline: Vietnam War Casualties
lead_paragraph: United States—45,933 killed and 303,616 wounded (with 153,300 of these requiring hospitalization).

headline: Trinity's Bells Ring Out
lead_paragraph: As soon as President Nixon ended his Vietnam peace announcement last night, Larry King, the organist at Trinity Church, went to an octaveand‐a‐half keyboard in the sanctuary and began pealing the 10 bells in the tower of the historic church at Broadway and Wall Street.

headline: THIEU IS CAUTIOUS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 24—President Nguyen Van Thieu, joining in announcing the Paris accord on Vietnam, declared today that he considered it only as a ceasefire and not as a guarantee of “a stable, long, lasting peace.”
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of the Speech by President on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's televised address to the nation last night on the Vietnam war, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: World Leaders Express Tributes
lead_paragraph: Following are tributes to former President Lyndon B. Johnson that were expressed yesterday:

headline: Communists Reported to Press Attacks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 24 (UPI)—An increase in Communist ground attacks throughout South Vietnam was reported early today shortly before it was announced that agreement had been reached on a cease‐fire and that it would go into effect this weekend.

headline: Major Hanoi Officials Reported Moving Into South, Perhaps to Establish a Capital
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23—United States intelligence sources report that Hanoi has, moved officials from its Ministries of Health and Educetion into South Vietnam's northernmost province in recent weeks, possibly to establish a Communist capital there for the South.

headline: TROOPS TO LEAVE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23—President Nixon said tonight that Henry A. Kissinger and North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, had initialed, an agreement in Paris today, “to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia.”
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: A Tree Grows in Texas
lead_paragraph: A 1967 visitor to Lyndon Johnson's ranch in Texas vies told by the then President: “This is the tree I expect to be buried under. And when my grandchildren see this tree I want them to think of me as the man who saved Asia and Vietnam and who did something for the Negroes in this country. Yet I have lost twenty popularity points on Vietnam and ten on the Negro question.”
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: Vietnam

headline: Trinity's Bells Ring Out News of Accord
lead_paragraph: As soon as President Nixon ended his Vietnam peace announcement last night, Larry King, the organist at Trinity Church, went to an octaveand‐a‐half keyboard in the sanctuary and began pealing the. 10 bells in the tower of the historic church at Broadway and Wall Street.

headline: Mass of Thanksgiving Is Celebrated by Cooke
lead_paragraph: Departing from his custom of celebrating weekday masses in his private chapel, Cardinal Cooke offered a noontime mass of thanksgiving for peace yesterday before 500 worshipers in St. Patrick's Cathedral and prayed that the impending cease‐fire would bring “lasting peace with justice” in Southeast Asia.

headline: Town That Paid High Price Recalls Its Dead
lead_paragraph: BEALLSVILLE, Ohio, Jan. 24—The wind whips through the wires up on Cemetery Hill here these days, rustling the long dried grass and banging the rope on the new metal flagpole.
author: By Andrew H. Malcolm Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 —“History shows that there is a major war every 22 years,” the Army captain said. “Maybe our cadets will escape the next one.”
author: By Harold Faber Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: FORT DIX, N. J., Jan. 24—No one threw his cap into the air or ordered a round for all at the bars of the officers and noncommissioned officers clubs here and at nearby Maguire Air Force Base last night.
author: By Richard J. H. Johnston Special to The New York Times

headline: ... and the Kissinger Role
lead_paragraph: In his impressive account yesterday of how agreement was reached on the war in Vietnam, Henry A. Kissinger observed almost parenthetically that “no one in the war has had a monopoly of anguish and ... no one in these debates has had a monopoly of moral insight.” If there was a defensive note in the comment, there need not have been; for Mr. Kissinger, emerging from his long ordeal of negotiation, clearly deserves the respect and admiration of the country.

headline: THO IS JUBILANT
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 24 — Le Duc Tho, North Vietnam's chief representative at the negotiations on a cease‐fire, declared today that the agreement initialed yesterday was “basically the same” as the draft reached in October, before the talks collapsed.

headline: PRICES SHOW DROP ON AMEX AND O‐T‐C
lead_paragraph: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over‐thecounter market dipped yesterday after opening strong. Profit‐taking seemed to be the reason rather than any reaction to the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement.
author: By James J. Nagle

headline: Impact of Paris Accord on Prisoners, Armed Forces and Politics in Indochina
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—The release of American prisoners of war is to begin by midFebruary under the peace agreement, with all the prisoners returned by the end of March.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: ... Motivations ...
lead_paragraph: An offhand quip by Mr. Kissinger at yesterday's briefing may well turn into the most revealing and provocative of all his remarks about the final phases President Nixon's war policy in Vietnam. Asked whether twelve days of saturation bombing of North Vietnam's cities and countryside late last month provided the final impetus to the agreement, the Presidential adviser wisely declined “to speculate on North Vietnamese motives.” Then he added, “I have too much trouble analyzing our own.”

headline: Signing: Convoluted Move
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan, 24—Because the Saigon and Vietcong authorities do not recognize each other, the signing of the Vietnam stettlement in Paris on Saturday will involve “a somewhat convoluted procedure,” in the words of Henry A. Kissinger.

headline: Hanoi Celebrates Truce Accord On the Streets and in the Palace
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 24 (Agence France‐Presse)—The news of the cease‐fire accord was heard on the streets of Hanoi this morning, broadcast by the street‐corner loudspeakers that only a few weeks ago warned that American bombers were coming.

headline: Capital Subdued After a ‘Long Agony’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—This time there was no dancing in the streets, no honking of horns, no champagne lifted in salutation, no slapping on the back —in short, no jubilation.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: THO IS JUBILANT
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 24 — Le Duc Tho, North Vietnam's chief representative at the negotiations on a cease‐fire, declared today that the agreement initialed yesterday was “basically the same” as the draft reached in October, before the talks collapsed.

headline: Pope Expresses Joy as World Capitals Welcome Coming Truce in Vietnam Fighting
lead_paragraph: In statements characterized by expressions of relief and hope for enduring peace, world leaders and governments yesterday welcomed the impending cessation of hostilities in Vietnam.
author: By Lawrence Van Gelder

headline: THE VIETNAM AGREEMENT AND PROTOCOLS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—Following, as made public by the White House today, are the texts of the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement initialed in Paris yesterday by Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, and of the four accompanying protocols detailing means of carrying it out. The accord and three of the protocols have been drafted in two versions. The “four‐party” versions will be signed Saturday morning. Because South Vietnam is unwilling to imply recognition, of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government, “two‐party” versions mentioning that Government will be signed in the afternoon only by the United States and North Vietnam.

headline: CAPITAL BRIEFING
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—Henry A. Kissinger said today that the United States had “a firm expectation” that the Vietnam cease‐fire that goes into effect on Saturday would soon extend to both Laos and Cambodia as well.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Stocks Tumble Despite Accord
lead_paragraph: The nation's financial markets moved sharply lower yesterday following President Nixon's disclosure Tuesday night that a cease‐fire agreement had been initialed. Investors were said to be focusing on the outlook for inflation, tight money and high interest rates under Phase 3—instead of on the approaching cease‐fire. Wall Street had been anticipating an end to the Vietnam war.

headline: Saigon Is Willing to Talk With Vietcong
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 25 — President Nguyen Van Thieu's closest adviser said today that the Government was prepared to meet with the National Liberation Front 24 hours after a ceasefire agreement is signed to discuss the political future of South Vietnam.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: In Maspeth, the Memory Of War's Cost Mutes Joy
lead_paragraph: In Wally's Bar in Maspeth, Queens, where the construction men stop to drink on their way home from work, there is a “Support Our P.O.W.'s” banner pasted on the telephone booth and a bartender who talks of killing during his tour in Vietnam.
author: By Georg Vecsey

headline: U.S. CUTS SHIPMENT, OF MEN TO VIETNAM,
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) —Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird announced tonight suspension of “virtually all per sonnel movements to Vietnam” by the Army, Air Force and Navy.

headline: In Maspeth, the Memory Of War's Cost Mutes Joy
lead_paragraph: In Wally's Bar in Maspeth, Queens, where the construction men stop to drink on their way home from work, there is a “Support Our P.O.W.'s” banner pasted on the telephone booth and a bartender who talks of killing during his tour in Vietnam.
author: By George Vecsey

headline: Bond Market Shows Narrow Range of Fluctuation
lead_paragraph: The bond market bobbed around within a narrow range yesterday, rising slightly on the announcement of the Vietnam ceasefire and then falling back.
author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr

headline: Excerpts From Thieu's Talk on Accord
lead_paragraph: Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from President Nguyen Van Thieu's radio speech in Saigon yesterday on the cease‐fire agreement. The excerpts appeared in late editions of The New York Times yesterday and are being reprinted to complete the documentary record of the Vietnam peace agreement.

headline: Vietnam Agreement...
lead_paragraph: The Vietnam settlement, which will bring an end to American participation in a war that has racked the United States for nearly a decade and could even conceivably bring peace to Indochina after a quarter‐century of hostilities, is a diplomatic triumph that will be welcomed by the people of America and of every other nation in the civilized world.

headline: How Compromise Was Reached
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 24—The ceasefire documents published tody came three months after untermittent but often extremely tense negotiations and 11 days of intensive bombing after a draft agreement was reached last October.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigonese React With Relief, Skepticism and Fear
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24—South Vietnamese greeted President Nguyen Van Thieu's announcement today of a ceasefire agreement with an ambivalent mixture of skepticism; relief and, for many, fear. There were no celebrations, no singing in the streets for the warweary residents of Saigon—only business as usual.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: End and Beginning
lead_paragraph: President Johnson died at about the moment the cease‐fire agreement was being initialed in Paris, giving at least a symbolic relation to the two events. And as President Nixon announced the cease‐fire, I could not help remembering—as perhaps some other listeners did—what Faulkner had old Dilsey say of the Compson family: “I seed de first en de last.”
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Among the Last G.I.'s, joy, Anger and Disbelief
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24—The last American soldiers in South Vietnam received the news today that the war was finally ending for them with emotions that ranged from elation and relief to disappointment, anger and resentment.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of Kissinger's News Briefing to Explain Vietnam Cease‐Fire Agreement
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Henry A. Kissinger's news conference in Washington yesterday on the Vietnam cease‐fire accord, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Dow Sinks 14.07 to Close at 1,004.59, Its Low for Day
lead_paragraph: Stock prices plunged yesterday in their biggest loss in almost 18 months as assorted economic worries outweighed the agreement to end the Vietnam war.
author: By Vartanig G. Vartan

headline: Business Hails Cease‐Fire but Sees No Dramatic Short‐Term Effect on Economy
lead_paragraph: While members of the business and financial community welcomed the announcement of a Vietnam cease‐fire agreement, most agreed yesterday that it would have no dramatic shortterm effect on industry or the economy.
author: By Ernest Holsendolph

headline: Concern Voiced on How Nation Has Changed
lead_paragraph: This is the way the war ends, not with a binge but a whimper; not with exultation but with relief; not with trumpets piercing but with the muted timbre of doubt and hope.
author: By Israel Shenker

headline: Transcript of Le Duc Tho's News Conference in Paris on the Vietnam Settlement
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 24 (Reuters) —Following, in unofficial translation from the French, is a transcript of Le Duc Tho's news conference today:

headline: Some Leaders in Congress Fear a Short‐Lived Truce
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 —Congressional leaders, including some prominent opponents of the Indochina war, gave President Nixon a standing ovation after a lengthy White House briefing this morning on the negotiated truce in Vietnam.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Stocks. Tumble Despite Accord
lead_paragraph: The nation's financial markets moved sharply lower yesterday following President Nixon's disclosure Tuesday night that a cease‐fire agreement had been initialed. Investors were said to be focusing on the outlook for inflation, tight money and high interest rates under Phase 3—instead of on the approaching cease‐fire. Wall Street had been anticipating an end to the Vietnam war.

headline: CAPITAL BRIEFING
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—Henry A. Kissinger said today that the United States had “a firm expectation” that the Vietnam cease‐fire that goes into effect on Saturday would soon extend to both Laos and Cambodia as well.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Peace‐at‐Hand’ Remark Alluded To by Kissinger
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—At a news conference on Oct. 26, Henry A. Kissinger told the nation that “peace was at hand” in Vietnam. As a delay developed in reaching a final settlement, his statement was often thrown in the Administration's face by its critics.

headline: Highlights of Agreement
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—Following are highlights the Vietnam agreement, as set out in the text and in news conference today by Henry A. Kissinger:

headline: PENTAGON PAPERS SHOWN TO JURORS
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24—The courtroom atmosphere in the Pentagon papers trial continued today to be as much schoolroom as courtroom, with the Government contending again that disclosure of the papers could have been “of use to a foreign nation.”
author: By Martin Arnold Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Air Raids Continue, But a Tapering Off Is Due
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 25 (AP) —United States and South Vietnamese planes reportedly continued their normal war operations throughout South Vietnam yesterday.

headline: Highlights of Agreement
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—Following are highlights of the Vietnam agreement, as set out in the text and in a news conference today by Henry A. Kissinger:

headline: A Happy Mood Grips 22 Families of P.O.W's on L.I.
lead_paragraph: BALDWIN, L.I., Jan. 24 —The first phone call Mrs. Jane Storms, sister of an Air Force prisoner of war, made last night after she learned her brother may be coming home was to cancel a full‐page advertisement scheduled for tomorrow publicizing the plight of the men being held in Southeast Asia.
author: By David A. Andelman Special to The New York Times

headline: Specialist Tom Davis: First to Fall in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 (UPI) — Eleven years and 31 days ago, on a dusty road in the hamlet of Duc Hoa near Saigon, the United States suffered its first Vietnam combat loss.

headline: Some Leaders in Congress Fear a Short‐Lived Truce
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 —Congressional leaders, including some prominent opponents of the Indochina war, gave President Nixon a standing ovation after a lengthy White House briefing this morning on the negotiated truce in Vietnam.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Politics: Its Future Rests on a Fragile Base
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—The political future of South Vietnam, at least in the first 90 days after the signing of the cease fire agreement Saturday, will rest in part on a fragile three‐party National Council of National Reconciliation and Concord whose eventual establishment—if it is established—will symbolize the heavy compromise worked out in the peace settlement.
author: By Seymour M. Hersh Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cease‐Fire Supervision: 4 Nations to Have a Role
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 —The detailed cease‐fire accord described today by Henry A. Kissinger provides for a complex series of truce supervisory teams intended to bring an end to major warfare in Indochina.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: News Adds Joy to Diamond Ball
lead_paragraph: Right up to the evening before the event, it looked as though the Diamond Ball would observe its 14th birthday in its usual manner, as —elegantly and unfussed as things can be done these days, Then President Nixon announced the Vietnam cease‐fire.
author: By Enid Nemy

headline: VIENTIANE HOPES
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25—Senior Laotian Government officials said today that they understood there was a secret agreement between North Vietnam and the United States under which Hanoi would withdraw 60,000 of its troops from Laos and a lesser num ber from South Vietnam.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETCONG OFFICERS ICE DUE IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 26—Vietnamese Communist military personnel will be flown to Saigon aboard American helicopters Sunday or Monday to join a cease‐fire commission created by the Vietnam peace accord, a well‐informed American source said yesterday.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: For Asian Development: Important Opportunity
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, Jan. 25 — The last shot of the Vietnam war will signal the beginning of new opportunity for the leaders of Asia, aided by the major powers, to come to grips with the basic problems of excessive population and poverty, which are already threatening the breakdown of many of their societies.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETCONG OFFICERS ARE DUE IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 26—Vietnamese Communist military personnel will be flown to Saigon aboard American helicopters Sunday or Monday to join a cease‐fire commission created by the Vietnam peace accord, a well‐informed American source said yesterday.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Look Back In Puzzlement
lead_paragraph: The Paris agreement extricates the United States from the Indochina war and sets a pattern for possible peace between Vietnam's two halves. But, in itself, it insures neither peace nor unification of that country nor does seem to guarantee a certain cease‐fire in neighboring Laos and Cambodia.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Voices of Conscience
lead_paragraph: Throughout the long years of America's ill‐fated involvement in the war in Indochina, the peace symbol remained a persistent expression of determination and hope. As time went on and the yearning for an end the bloodshed grew in intensity, that symbol's message became emblazoned in the minds and hearts of millions. It formed a nonpartisan bond for many who agreed on little else.

headline: Truce‐Control Nations Are Briefed by Rogers
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25—Well‐placed Administration officials said today that President Nixon would soon send Vice President Agnew to South Vietnam and other Southeast Asian countries to demonstrate continued American support in the wake of the signing Saturday of a Vietnam cease‐fire agreement.

headline: The South Vietnamese Economy: Depression and Joblessness Ahead
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 — The peace agreement between North Vietnam and the United States has one provision that stood out as improbable when the Communists broadcast it in October. “Peace and national independence) must be closely linked with the exercise of broad democratic freedoms,” the Hanoi radio said, “including guarantees for the right to private ownership and for freedom of enterprise, as provided for in the said agreement.”
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Gallup Poll Finds U.S. Divided on Bombing
lead_paragraph: Americans were almost evenly divided in their opinion of the heavy bombing of North Vietnam that preceded the final truce negotiations, according to a nationwide Gallup poll completed just before President Nixon announced on Jan. 15 a suspension of the raids.

headline: Jobs and Profits: Peace Unlikely to Bring Change
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25—For the United States domestic economy, the Vietnam war is likely to end with neither a boom nor a bust.
author: By Philip Shabecoff Special to The New York Times

headline: Japan Asks Role in Postwar Planning for Indochina
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Jan. 25 — Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan indicated today that his Government expected to be consulted fully by the United States and other major nations on any international plan for the postwar reconstruction of Indochina.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Canadians Could Begin Truce Duty on Monday
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Jan. 25—The way was being rapidly cleared today for the first contingent of Canadian truce observers to leave for South Vietnam as soon as the Paris agreement is signed Saturday. Some 150 to 180 officers could be on duty there by Monday.
author: By Jay Walz Special to The New York Times

headline: Plea by My Lai Figure To Remain Officer Denied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) —The Army rejected yesterday ??n appeal by Capt. Eugene Ko??ouc, exonerated of charges in ??onnection with the slaying of ??ivilians at the Vietnamese ??amlet of My Lai, that he be ??llowed to remain on active ??uty as an officer.

headline: VIENTIANE HOPES
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25—Senior Laotian Government officials said today that they understood there was a secret agreement between North Vietnam and the United States under which Hanoi would withdraw 60,000 of its troops from Laos and a lesser number from South Vietnam.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Military Commitments: Big Role and Risks Will Continue
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 —For the United States the end of seven bloody, costly, frustrating and inconclusive years in Vietnam is not the end of its military commitments abroad. It will continue to have a sizable military presence, with all the risks involved, in many parts of the world.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: The Cease‐Fire Accords and Beyond: Some Questions and Answers
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25—The cease‐fire agreement between Hanoi and Washington, which President Nixon has said wil “end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia,” will be signed in Paris Saturday and go into effect that evening.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Aftermath
lead_paragraph: It's over. Or at least it is supposed to be tomorrow; completion and announcement of agreement between the United States and North Vietnam did not deter final, senseless acts of combat just before the cease‐fire to take effect.

headline: A TRUCE AWAITED
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 25—A high diplomatic source said today that Cambodia would announce a halt in her offensive military operations by Sunday fie said that the step was planned on the strength of American assurances that the United States and North Vietnam had reached an understanding during their Paris talks that the cease‐fire in Vietnam would be extended to Laos and Cambodia as well.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: 100‐Man P.O.W. Airlifts Expected to Start Feb. 10
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25—State Department officials expect North Vietnam to release American prisoners of war in groups of about 100 men, starting about Feb. 10. And the Defense Department has placed on alert an elaborate Medical ‐ airlift operation to start flying them home.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Helsinki‐Hanoi Ties
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 25 (Reuters) — Finland established diplomatic relations with North Vietnam today, the Foreign Ministry announced. It said ambassadors would be exchanged within three months. Finland has no relations with South Vietnam.

headline: Market Place:
lead_paragraph: The stock market should have gone up. President Nixon had announced the longawaited cease‐fire in Vietnam and Wednesday was going to be the day of the peace rally, when investors would shake off the apathy of war and don the euphoria of peace.
author: By Terry Robards

headline: THO IS LEAVING FOR HANOI TODAY
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 25 — Preparations were under way today for the final act in the five long years of Paris peace talks—Saturday's signing of the agreements ending the Vietnam war.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Extensive TV Coverage Of Signing Is Arranged
lead_paragraph: The television networks will provide videotaped and live coverage of the signing of the Vietnam agreements in Paris tomorrow.

headline: Saigon Is Over‐Equipped in Planes
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25—Racing against the time when a cease‐fire goes into effect, the United States has swamped the South Vietnamese Air Force with hundreds of warplanes it can neither fly nor maintain.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: A TRUCE AWAITED
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 25—A high diplomatic source said today that Cambodia would halt her offensive military operations by Sunday on the strength of American assurances that Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho had reached an understanding during their negotiations that the cease‐fire in Vietnam would be extended to Laos and Cambodia as well.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: American Dies in Shelling Of Air Base Near Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 26—In a surge of Communist ground attacks throughout South Vietnam, a barrage of rockets was fired early today into the Bien Hoa Base near Saigon, killing one American and wounding nine.

headline: An Old Hand at Truces
lead_paragraph: When Maj. Gen., Gilbert Hume Woodward was last in charge of overseeing an Asian cease‐fire—the one in Korea—he honed and developed a gift for negotiation and coolness under insult, innuendo and harangue.

headline: U.S. Names General to Head Delegation to Four Power Cease‐Fire Commission
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26—Maj. Gen. Gilbert H. Woodward, a tough 55‐year‐old veteran of negotiations with the North Korean Communists, has been designated to command the United States delegation to the four‐power joint military commission that will help supervise the coming Vietnam cease‐fire.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You said in an editorial (Jan. 5) that Prime Minister Jack Lynch of the Republic of Ireland would “use his five days in this country to dissuade IrishAmericans from contributing funds ostensibly for relief in Northern Ireland but used to buy guns, and ammunition for the Irish Republican Army Provisions's.” You were quite right. Mr. Lynch has been on television shows here saying exactly that and suggesting that those who wished to help the beleaguered Nationalists of Northern Ireland should do so through the Irish Red Cross. He omitted to say that the Irish Red Cross has no jurisdiction in Northern Ireland and in fact can distribute no relief—and has distributed none—to the Nationalists of Northern Ireland during the of turmoil since 1969.

headline: CEASE‐FIRE TEAMS AWAITED IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26—Polish and Canadian diplomats said today they were doubtful that the international commission intended to supervise the cease‐fire in South Vietnam would be able to establish a functioning headquarters within the time specified in the protocols of the peace agreement.

headline: For the Vietnamese, No Cessation of Pain
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South VietnamFor most of the people of South Vietnam the end of the war—if it is the end of their war—is coming far too late for rejoicing.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: TAY NINH REPORTS ATTACK BY ENEMY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 27—Communist troops reportedly attacked Tay Ninh city west of Saigon this morning as they stepped up their assaults throughout South Vietnam in preparation for tomorrow's cease‐fire.

headline: Fort Monmouth Hospital Gets Ready To Give Freed P.O.W.'s ‘Best’ Care
lead_paragraph: FORT MONMOUTH, Jan. 26 —Final touches were being put today on plans at Patterson Army Hospital here to receive and care for freed Army prisoners from Vietnam whose homes and families are in the New Jersey and New York metropolitan area.
author: By Richard J. H. Johnston Special to The New York Times

headline: Post‐Vietnam Priorities
lead_paragraph: Administration officials have confirmed that, so far as they are concerned, there will be no post‐Vietnam “peace dividend” to be used for meeting the needs of the cities and other long‐neglected domestic problems.

headline: SAFETY OF PRISONERS IN SAIGON DOUBTED
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Jan. 26—Amnesty International expressed fear today for the safety of political prisoners in South Vietnam.

headline: CEASE‐FIRE TEAMS AWAITED IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 26—Polish and Canadian diplo mats said today they were doubtful that the international commission intended to super vise the cease‐fire in Spouth Vietnam would be able to establish a functioning head quarters within the time specitied in the protocols of the peace agreement.

headline: For the Vietnamese, No Cessation of Pain,
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam—For most of the people of South Vietnam the end of the war—if it is the end of their war—is coming far too late for rejoicing.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: The Last Man
lead_paragraph: In a war that has never made much sense at best, it seems uniquely, senseless that soldiers and civilians are being killed in these waning hours between President Nixon's announcement Tuesday of a peace agreement and the, moment this evening when the cease‐fire formally takes effect. For the families of these final victims of the war, the circumstances lend an added poignancy to their grief.

headline: The Last Tango
lead_paragraph: PARIS‐The second Indochina war is ending as it began, in obscurity and contradiction. It is like a Pirandello play, confounding appearance and reality. But as in Pirandello, there is profound theme to be found amid the confusion.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: TAY NINH REPORTS ATTACK BY ENEMY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 27—Communist troops reportedly attacked Tay Ninh city west of Saigon this morning as they stepped up their assaults throughout South Vietnam in preparation for tomorrow's cease‐fire.

headline: MUNITIONS PLANT IN JERSEY CLOSES
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Jan. 26—The Burlington Army Ammunition Plant, which as recently as last October employed 600 people making mortar shells for use in the war in Vietnam, closed its production line today. Only 25 maintenance workers will be retained.

headline: Giap Hails Hanoi People On Victory Over B‐52's
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 26 (Agence France Presse)—The North Vietnamese Defense Minister, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, smiling and happy on the stage of the municipal stadium here, congratulated the population of Hanoi today on its “victory” over the American. B‐52 bombers.

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: Henry A. Kissinger promised members of Congress yesterday that the Administration would consult them before making any firm commitments to North Vietnam on postwar aid programs. On the eve of the formal signing in Paris of the Vietnam cease‐fire accord, Mr. Kissinger made an unusual trip to the Capitol to brief Senators and Representatives on the agreement's terms. [Page 1, Column 1.]

headline: Screen: Wives in 'Limbo':Robson Views P.O.W. Families at Festival
lead_paragraph: If it has nothing else — and Mark Robson's "Limbo" hasn't — you might at least expect topicality of a film about the problems facing wives of American servicemen who are either missing in action in Vietnam or prisoners of war. By using something less than the sheerest art, Robson manages to make this story ("torn from today's headlines," we are told) resemble any number of dreadful World War II tearjerkers."Interestingly, however, "Limbo" does demonstrate the impotency of so much of the liberal opposition to the war that is now, apparently, coming to an end.Robson is, I take it, a liberal. He certainly was back in the late ninteen-forties when he directed such films as "Champion" and "Home of The Brave."In that optimistic time, political and social issues were clear cut. War against bigotry was simply an extension of the war against Hitler. It was cosily patriotic. The good, voting liberal had not yet had to wrestle with the unruly, rising consciousnesses of all sorts of impatient groups, with, for example, the new black philosophy that says to hell with integration, we'll do it by ourselves.A lot of liberals lost heart in the nineteen-fifties and sixties. It is not fun being ridiculed by the people you had always wanted to protect. Robson, for reasons of his own, has devoted most of his later career to big-budget nonsense on the order of "Peyton Place," "Von Ryan's Express" and "Valley of The Dolls." Watching "Limbo," you can speculate why.The mind that made it is, I suspect, outraged by the war but seems afraid to say so. It is as split in mood as a lot of other people may be split in their sympathies — feeling sorrow for the American P.O.W. fliers, yet overwhelmed by fury with those who continued to go on bombing missions.The liberals protested but mostly with a politeness born, I think, out of memories of World War II, and even Korea, when wars were declared and the stakes were easy to define. There is a similar liberal sort of politeness in 'Limbo," which is as obvious in its narrative structure and physical look as in anything that anyone says.The screenplay, by Joan Silver and James Bridges, set on an Air Force base in Florida, is about three wives who are three points of view, good, bad and all mixed-up.The good wife (Kathleen Nolan) is middle-aged, Catholic, the mother of four, faithful to her husband and angry about the war.The bad one (Katherine Justice) is rich, beautiful, Southern, an all-out patriot and so spoiled that she refuses to believe the eyewitness report of her husband's death.The confused one is Kate Jackson, married only two weeks before her husband's departure, and now hopelessly in love with a nice, honorable, out-of-work space technician.The situations are real enough, but Robson entombs them in a lot of bogus domestic complications, photographed and acted in a simplistic romantic style that denies any sense of real topicality and urgency. If Vietnam were a war like any other (which it is not), there might be a small point to this approach.Only occasionally does the film seem to be about a special, very confused moment in history, but Robson tends to flub these moments too, as in the sequence in which three American wives visit the North Vietnamese embassy in Paris. He opens the sequence with some nice old chop-chop music that 40 years ago used to identify a stock shot of wicked Shanghai.Robson's heart is in the right place, but his movie is unimaginative, phony and ineffectual. It opened yesterday at the Festival.
author: By Vincent Canby

headline: KISSINGER VOWS A CONGRESS ROLE IN AID FOR HANOI
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 —Henry A. Kissinger promised members of Congress today that the Nixon Administration would consult with them before making any firm commitments to North Vietnam on postwar aid programs.

headline: Air Team Due in Saigon Today to Speed Pullout
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26—A team of about 75 Air Force transportation specialists is expected to arrive here tomorrow to help speed the airlift of the remaining American troops out of South Vietnam, American officers said today.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Mr. Peacemaker’ Nixon Is Welcomed in Florida
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD AIR FORCE, BASE, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) —President Nixon was greeted today by hundreds of people as he arrived for a weekend stay at Key Biscayne. He told the families of Vietnam war prisoners that he wished he could have brought them home earlier.

headline: No Goulash or Kielbasa For Truce Supervisors
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (UPI)—There will behamburgers and fried chicken instead of goulash and kielbasa for the Hungarian and Polish members of the International Control Commission when they arrive in Vietnam this weekend. And the Indonesians may have to get used to American versions of Asian foods.

headline: President's Proclamation
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 26—Following is the text of a proclamation by President Nixon calling for a national moment of prayer and thanksgiving, issued today at the Florida White House:
author: Special to The New York Times; Richard Nixon

headline: KISSINGER VOWS A CONGRESS ROLE IN AID FOR HANOI
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 —Henry A. Kissinger promised members of Congress today that the Nixon Administration would consult with them before making any firm commitments to North Vietnam on postwar aid programs.

headline: ‘Paid’ Sign Will Flash In Times Square Today
lead_paragraph: An illuminated sign bearing the word “peace” will flash in Times, Square tomorrow evening when the ceasefire in Vietnam takes effect.

headline: 600 Are Laid Off by Jersey Company That Made Shells for Use in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Jan. 26 —The Burlington Army Ammunition Plant, which as recently as last October employed 600 people making mortar shells for use in the war in Vietnam, closed its production line today. Only 25 maintenance workers will be retained.

headline: A Reluctant G.I.'s Life and Death
lead_paragraph: ST. JOSEPH, Mo.—The house ?? Penn Street where Charley Stockbauer used to live sits ?? a historic crossroads of America.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETNAM PEACE PACTS SIGNED; AMERICA'S LONGEST WAR HALTS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 27—The Vietnam cease‐fire agreement was signed here today in eerie silence, without a word or a gesture to express the world's relief that the years of war were officially ending.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Waldheim Offers U.N. Aid In Recovery for Vietnam
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 (Reuters) — Secretary General Waldheim offered the help of the United Nations today in the “urgent priority” task of rehabilitation and reconstruction in Vietnam.

headline: The Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was an almost audible sigh of relief on Capitol Hill last week when the declaration of a Vietnam accord wiped out the chief stimulus of the Congressional movement to recapture power from the White House. Yet, curiously enough, by halting combat in Indochina, President Nixon may have increased the prospects of an all‐out battle with Congress.
author: James M. Naughton

headline: Chronology of the War in Vietnam and Its Historical Antecedents From 1940
lead_paragraph: Following is a chronology of the Vietnam war and its historical antecedents:

headline: Reconciliation...
lead_paragraph: At the close of his extraordinary televised press conference explaining the terms of the. Vietnam settlement last week, Henry Kissinger concluded his statement with a fervent expression of hope and determination that could not have failed to move his listeners, regardless of their position during the long, divisive conflict that now finally appears to be ended. It was a sentiment that the President himself would have done well to voice.

headline: ‘We Shall Overcome’
lead_paragraph: Lyndon Baines Johnson, the 36th President of the United States, was in some ways a tragic figure. He had great gifts, aspired to do noble deeds, worked with heroic energy and intensity, accomplished much, and was finally brought low by a cataclysmic error of judgment. His extraordinary life was a drama of classical proportions.

headline: An Advance Group From Hanoi Stops At Laotian Airport
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sunday, Jan. 28—Nineteen North Vietnamese officers and one civilian member of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government arrived here from Hanoi today in transit to Saigon, and the leader of the group said he was optimistic that the peace that went itno effect this morning morning would be durable.

headline: Some Lessons From Phase 2
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — C. Jackson Grayson Jr. is that rarest of American birds, the tameduck price regulator.
author: By Edward Cowan

headline: Peace And the Campus
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.H.—This has been a bad winter for skiing and the beautiful campus of Dartmouth College has been decked out in dirty sludge rather than the white drifts of snow usually associated with the Winter Carnival. So there was not even the call of the slopes to deflect students attention last week from the coming of a ceasefire in Vietnam.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
lead_paragraph: ONE long‐standing pressure point on the economic scene was finally removed last week with the signing of the cease‐fire agreement in the Vietnam war, but others were becoming tighter and more irritating in the business and investment worlds.
author: By Thomas E. Mullaney

headline: PLEDGES TO THIEU BY U.S. REPORTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 28—The United States has given “official” and private assurances to Saigon that it will intervene immediately if the Communists commit any “blatant” violations of the Vietnam cease‐fire, a wellinformed South Vietnamese official said yesterday.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: American M.P.'s Grumble About Communist Facilities
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (UPI) — Disgruntled American military policemen complained today that the United States was providing better facilities for the North Vietnamese coming to Saigon than are given to United States soldiers.

headline: Soviet Hails Vietcong Leaders and Sees Ultimate Triumph of Their Cause
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan 27 — The Soviet Union's leaders pledged continued support to Vietcong leaders today and expressed confidence that their cause would ultimately triumph in South Vietnam.

headline: HIDING OF U.S. SPY DENIED BY WILSON
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)—Former Prime Minister Harold Wilson denied today a report that he hid an American spy in his residence outside London where he met with Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin in 1967 for secret talks on Vietnam.

headline: All Quiet Along the Potomac?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 — It rained quietly and steadily in Washington the day the guns stopped in Vietnam. From the Lee Mansion and the Kennedy grave on the Virginia slope, across the Potomac to the Congressional building on Capitol Hill, everything was blurred and quiet.
author: By James Reston

headline: What Vietnam Did to the American Economy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The war in Vietnam produced what is widely recognized as the greatest blunder in Government economic policy since World War II — a blunder whose effects have still not been entirely eliminated.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr

headline: Nation Celebrates Peace In Prayer and Muted Joy
lead_paragraph: President Nixon, like millions of other Americans, watched the signing of the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement on television yesterday and then, like many others, took part in modest and somber celebration of the end of a tragic war.
author: By Michael Knight

headline: U.S. Asks Feb. 26 Start For Vietnam Conference
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The—United States formally proposed today that the 12‐nation conference on guaranteeing the peace in Vietnam be convened on Feb. 26.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Scars of the Past...
lead_paragraph: “Good evening. I have asked for this radio and television time tonight for the purpose of announcing that we have today concluded an agreement to end the war....” With these words of President Nixon last Tuesday, the images of a tragic decade began to recede into history: The proliferating tombstones at Arlington National Cemetery ... the tangled bodies of the Mylal massacre ... the horror of a young woman over the death of a fellow student at Kent State University ... the terror of a naked, napalmed Vietnam child ... the ravaged remains of Quangtri City ... and the face of a President whose ambitions, for nation and self, were frustrated by a war he sought to end by escalation. Last Monday, scant hours before Mr. Nixon's announcement, Lyndon Baines Johnson died in San Antonio.

headline: South Vietnamese Adjust Exchange Rate of Currency
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (Reuters) — South Vietnam today adjusted the exchange rate for its currency, changing the price for one United States dollar from 465 to 475 piasters.

headline: Other News About Accords
lead_paragraph: CAMBODIA —The exiled Cambodian head of state said in Peking that his guerrilla forces would fight on despite the cease‐fire in Vietnam. Cambodia announced a suspension of offensive activities tomorrow. [Page 26.]

headline: BATTLES CONTINUE AFTER CEASE‐FIRE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 28—A cease‐fire officially went into effect throughout Vietnam at 8 A.M. today, but widespread fighting continued and there were reports that an unarmed American helicopter sent to pick up a Vietcong delegation and bring it to Saigon had been shot down over Tay Nin Ninh Province.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Prince Sihanouk Says That the Fighting Will Continue in Cambodia but That He Is Open to Talks With U.S.
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Jan. 27 (Reuters)—The exiled Cambodian head of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, said today that his guerrilla forces would fight on despite the cease‐fire in Vietnam.

headline: PATHET LAO GIVES NO HINT OF PEACE
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 27—Gen. Phoune Sipraseuth, head of the Pathet Lao negotiating team in the Laos peace talks, returned here today from consultations in Samneua and Hanoi. Despite the cease‐fire in Vietnam, he gave no indication that peace in Laos could now be concluded quickly.
author: By Malcolm M. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: Australia/New Zealand
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Since forging a Pacific partnership in World War II, the United States, Australia and New Zealand have followed largely similar policies in Asia. Australian and New Zealand troops served in Korea. And, while most other American allies balked, the Anzacs joined the Americans in Vietnam.

headline: Pope Asking Italians To Give for Vietnam
lead_paragraph: ROME, Jan. 27 (UPI)—Pope Paul VI has instructed Italian bishops to set aside Sunday, Feb. 4, in all the country's churches as a day of prayer and special collections for the reconstruction of Vietnam, the Vatican announced today.

headline: Hanoi Lists of P.O.W.'s Are Made Public by U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27—The State Department tonight released the list of American civilians acknowledged by North Vietnam as having been captured in South Vietnam during the Vietnam war. The list left about half the 51 American civilians believed missing or captured unaccounted for.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Cease‐fire
lead_paragraph: After all the death and destruction, the settlement finally written simply codified the military stalemate of the long war. The United States agreed to depart without a guarantee of the survival of an independent, anti‐Communist South Vietnam. North Vietnam agreed to stop fighting without a guarantee of a Communist‐dominated coalition government in Saigon. Both sides agreed to leave the South's future to a political contest among Vietnamese.

headline: TANAKA PROPOSES A PARLEY ON ASIA
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Jan. 27—Premier Kakuei Tanaka tentatively proposed today that a conference of Asian and Pacific nations be convened to secure the postVietnam peace of Asia.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: The Toll: 12 Years of War
lead_paragraph: Military

headline: Truce Supervisors From Poland, Hungary and Canada Leave for South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Jan. 27—A contingent of 75 Polish military officers and civilians left here tonight to join Hungarian, Canadian and Indonesian units in supervising the Vietnam ceasefire.
author: By James Feron Special to The New York Times

headline: Cost to an Economy
lead_paragraph: From a cold business point of view, World War II was a blessing for the United States: It lifted a depressed economy up to full employment and made this country not only the arsenal of democracy but its financial, capital as well. By contrast, the Vietnam war was an unmitigated drain. Since the economy was already close to full employment in 1965 when President Johnson began his major escalation, the war put an extra strain on national resources and kicked off an inflation that has been difficult to root out.
author: Leonard S. Silk

headline: P.O.W. Kin in Tristate Area Rejoice
lead_paragraph: At 7:30 Saturday, evening a Casualty Assistance Calls Officer from the Department of Defense phoned the home of Mrs. Loyal Goodermote to tell her that the name of her son, Wayne K. Goodermote, a Navy lieutenant, was included in the list of prisoners of war issued by North Vietnam.
author: By Michael T. Kaufman

headline: Lon Nol Orders Army to Cease Fire
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 28—President Lon Nol made an attempt today to bring about peace in Cambodia on the basis of the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Long Wait Over for 1,925 U. S. Families
lead_paragraph: Jo Anne Flora has been waiting for six years. Her husband, Sgt. 1st Cl. Carroll E. Flora Jr., was listed as missing after he fell from a medical evacuation helicopter near the Demilitarized Zone and disappeared.
author: By Steven V. Roberts

headline: Communists List 555 P.O.W.'s but Give No Data on Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28—The Communist side has notified the United States that it holds 555 American military prisoners in North and South Vietnam who will be released within the next two months.

headline: PEKING VOICES HOPE FOR VIETNAM PEACE
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Monday, Jan. 29—China has expressed the hope that all signatories to the Vietnam peace agreement will “earnestly carry out” its terms.

headline: Fighting Rages Along Route 1 After Truce
lead_paragraph: TRANG BANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 28—At exactly 8 A.M. today the American Armed Forces Radio began reading President Nixon's proclamation of thanksgiving for “the end of the war in Vietnam” and the “beginning of a new era of world peace.”
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: Listing of American Prisoners, Taken From Names Provided by Communists
Truce Team Eager but Behind Schedule
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29—Two Soviet airliners flew into Tan Son Nhut Air Base yesterday afternoon carrying Hungarian and Polish soldiers and political officers who will represent their countries on the international commission to supervise the cease‐fire.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: He'll Be Coming Home But Both Parents Died
lead_paragraph: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 28 (UPI)—The homecoming of Lieut. Comdr. Frederick R. Purrington of the Navy, a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for seven years, will be a hollow one. His father and mother have both died and he does not know it.

headline: An Army Colonel From Michigan Is Last American to Die in War
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Jan. 28—Lieut. Col. William B. Nolde, 43, of Mount Pleasant, Mich., was identified by the Pentagon today as the last American to die in the Vietnam war.
author: By Jerry M. Flint Special to The New York Times

headline: Lessons of War: Vietnam Spurs a Sweeping Review of Tactics and Weapons
lead_paragraph: This is the last of three articles on the United States willed forces in the aftermath of the Vietnam war.
author: By Drew Middleton

headline: Tensions of Talking
lead_paragraph: Negotiations are a means to an end. Serious problems can arise when nations spend so much of their creative energies on getting talks started that they grow inarticulate about how the talks should end, about the desired outcome. This is a looming danger in the twelve‐nation Vietnam peace conference which the United States is moving to get under way Feb. 26. seems already to be the fate of the long‐awaited EastWest talks to reduce military forces deployed in Central Europe.

headline: 100 ‐PLANE STRIKE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 —About 100 American planes, including B‐52 bombers, attacked suspected Communist positions and supply lines in Laos after the Vietnam cease‐fire went into effect, Administration officials said today.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: In Quang Tri Area, the War's Greatest Battleground, Truce Begins in Name Only
lead_paragraph: QUANG TRI, South Vietnam, Jan. 28—The artillery stopped firing at this greatest of all South Vietnamese battlegrounds at 8:05 this morning, five minutes late.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Other News About Indochina
lead_paragraph: TRUCE OBSERVERS — An advance party of North Vietnamese and Vietcong representatives arrived in Saigon but refused to leave the aircraft in protest against a requirement that they fill out South Vietnamese landing cards. Hungarian and Polish soldiers and political officers also arrived. [Page 13.]

headline: FIGHTING DECLINES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29 — The South Vietnamese Government said today that the Communists committed hundreds of ceasefire violations during the first 22 hours of the formal truce but indicated that almost all of them were minor.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Communist Delegates Balk at Saigon Procedure and Stay on Plane for Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29—After a war of nerves that lasted almost 24 hours, the South Vietnamese Government this afternoon agreed to allow a group of vietcong military representatives to leave a plane at Tan Son Nhut airport without filling out immigration forms.

headline: Other News About Indochina
lead_paragraph: COMMUNIST TEAMS—An advance party of North Vietnamese and Vietcong representatives arrived in Saigon but refused to leave the aircraft until South Vietnamese dropped a requirement that they fill out landing cards. Two American planes flew to Hanoi to pick up about 150 military men who will help supervise the truce. [Page 13.]

headline: 100‐PLANE STRIKE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 —About 100 American planes, including B‐52 bombers, attacked suspected Communist positions and supply lines in Laos after the Vietnam cease‐fire went into effect, Administration officials said today.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Crowds Turn Out At Dawn to Hear News
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)—Hundreds of thousands of people thronged the streets of Hanoi shortly after dawn today to hear the Vietnam radio announce over its public address system that hostilities had officially come to an end.

headline: Negotiator Behind Truce Scenesn
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan, 28—During the October news conference in which he proclaimed that “peace is at hand,” Henry A, Kissinger noted that none of the issues involved in the negotiations were simple.

headline: PRAVDA SAYS SOVIET RUSHED HANOI ARMS
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (Reuters) —The Soviet Union rushed some of its weapons, including antiaircraft missiles and fighter planes to North Vietnam to counter the last major United States bombing campaign there, Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, said today.

headline: Fighting Rages Along Route 1 After Truce
lead_paragraph: TRANG BANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 28—At exactly 8 A.M. today the American Armed Forces Radio began reading President Nixon's proclamation of thanksgiving for “the end of the war in Vietnam” and the “beginning of a new era of world peace.”
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: '54 and '73 Pacts Strongly Alike
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28—The agreement that Secretary of State William P. Rogers signed yesterday in Paris bears a remarkable resemblance in its basic provisions to the Geneva accords of 1954.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: FIGHTING DECLINES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29 — The South Vietnamese Government said today that the Communists committed hundreds of ceasefire violations during the first 22 hours of the formal truce but indicated that almost all of them were minor.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: The Political Struggle
lead_paragraph: PARIS—In thinking about the ceasefire in Vietnam, Americans quite naturally wonder whether the enforcement apparatus will be swift and effective enough to stop Communist violations. But it is important to recognize that the other side has its own interest in enforcement of the Paris agreement.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Agnew Is Off for Saigon On 7‐Nation Asia Tour
lead_paragraph: ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE, Md., Jan. 28 (AP)—Vice President Agnew departed today for Saigon on a seven‐nation Asian tour just 15 hours after the start of the Vietnam cease‐fire.

headline: Thieu Letter Thanks U.S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28—President Nguyen Van Thieu has written a letter to President Nixon expressing his “heartfelt gratitude for the great sacrifices that the United States has made throughout so many years to help us defend our freedom ana our right of selfdetermination.”

headline: Democrats Held Likely To Restore Johnson
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28—When Lyndon Johnson live and the war in Vietnam cotinued, national Democrat raced each other to escape the long shadow that their last President had cast on the party Already, however, many Democrats see his reputation being redeemed and his influence restored in death—even to the point, some say, that by the time the next President is nominated, Mr. Johnson could be the supreme model for Democratic candidates.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘A Good Feeling’ Surges Over Home in Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: It's been five Christmases, three family deaths, two marriages, two nieces and one nephew since Army Sgt. James Alexander Daly, taken prisoner in South Vietnam in January, 1968, has seen his family and their three‐story home on block of neat brownstones in the Bedford‐Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
author: By Ronald Smothers

headline: For L.I. Wife of P.O.W., Dawn Comes at Midnight
lead_paragraph: WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 29—Carol Baker, wife of Air Force Capt. David E. Baker, remembers the exact minute the telephone call came. “It was five minutes to midnight Saturday night,” she said.
author: By David A. Andelman Special to The New York Times

headline: McGuire Ready to Bring P.O.W.'s Home
lead_paragraph: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J. Jan. 29— The largest military air command departure and arrival point on the East Coast stood poised today to play a role in the return of military prisoners of war from Vietnam.
author: By Richard J. H. Johnston Special to The New York Times

headline: Albany Will Get Bills to Bar ‘Inequities’ in Social Security Rise
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Jan. 29 — The Democratic minority in the State Senate announced today that they would submit a package of bills designed to correct “gross inequities” resulting from the recent Social Security increase, which, they said, would endanger the Medicaid and welfare eligibility of thousands of elderly people.
author: By Francis X. Clines Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Troops Selectively Ignore Truce
lead_paragraph: CAM LONG, South Vietnam, Jan. 29— South Vietnamese forces were openly ignoring the cease‐fire agreement in the area northwest of Saigon today, but on a relatively small scale and selectively.
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: Zambia Urges U.N. Censures in Dispute
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 29—Zambia asked the Security Council today to condemn Rhodesia, charging that the whiteruled African nation had carried out aggressive acts, economic blackmail and military threats that could create a new “Vietnam situation” in southern Africa.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch Special to The New York Times

headline: The Georgetown Blacking Factory
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—On the C.B.S. Evening News, Monday, Jan. 8, 1973, Dan Rather announced to the twenty million faithful followers of the Cronkite show that the reported rift between the President and Henry Kissinger was “past the rumor stage to the fact stage.” He thereby elevated to gospel that which had been for weeks the speculation of Washington commentators and columnists.
author: By Charles W. Colson

headline: British Government Thinks U.N. Should Oversee Vietnam Peace
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Jan. 29—The Britsh Government believes that ??he problem of maintaining the ??eace in Vietnam should even??ually be turned over to the United Nations.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Next Vietnam Parley
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 29 — Plans are advancing to nail down the Vietnam accords with international guarantees, even though, at least at the outset, the ceasefire may be proving “fragile,” to use President Nixon's word.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Books of The Times
lead_paragraph: SOLDIER. By Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, retired. With James T. Wooten. 495 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.95.

headline: Amnesty for Draft Resisters Is Expected to Be Divisive Political Issue for Years
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 —Like the Vietnam war itself, the issue of amnesty for those who refused to fight seems likely to be a divisive and emotional part of the American political scene for many years.
author: By Anthony Ripley Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON AND THE VIETCONG CHARGE FIGHTING GOES ON; U.S. AIDES TERM IT ‘LIGHT’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 30—The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of additional ceasefire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as “scattered light activity” that was gradually diminishing in intensity.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Johnson Was Informed About Trace, Wife Says
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., Jane 29 (AP) —Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that her husband knew a cease‐fire agreement had been reached before his death last Monday. She said he had been told personally by President Nixon.

headline: Bond Interest Rates Continue to Climb
lead_paragraph: The credit markets, in a reaction that apparently had little connection with either the cease‐fire in Vietnam or with President Nixon's budget message, continued in a slump yesterday. Tax‐exempt bond yields rose particularly sharply. Sereral major new bond issues that had been brought to market last week were permitted to trade without any, support from under. writers yesterday, and prices sank. These setbacks set the stage for today's sales of triple‐A Texas Power & Light Company bonds in the corporate bond sector and of triple‐A Illinois and California issues in the taxexempt area.
author: By John H. Allan

headline: U.S. Says 56 Prisoners Remain Unaccounted For
U.S. Copter Pilot Dies Of Wounds After Truce
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29 (AP)—A United States helicopter pilot, wounded while flying an aircraft reported to bear marks of neutrality, died today. He was the first American killed in Vietnam since the cease‐fire went into effect.

headline: Mixed Force, With US. Advisers Guards Key Highway as War Goes On in Laos
lead_paragraph: MUONG KASSY, Laos, Jan. 29—While the war in Vietnam may be sputtering to a ceasefire, the war in Laos continues.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON AND THE VIETCONG CHARGE FIGHTING GOES ON; U.S. AIDES TERM IT ‘LIGHT’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 30—The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of additional ceasefire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as “scattered light activity” that was gradually diminishing in intensity.
author: By Edward Cowan

headline: Military Commission Bogs Down Over Vietcong's Refusal to Present Credentials
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 30 — The military commission that is to help monitor the Vietnam cease‐fire held its first meeting yesterday, but it immediately became bogged down in a procedural dispute as the Vietcong delegates refused to present their credentials, well‐informed sources said.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Lodge Says He Saw Little Prospect of a Truce Accord
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 —Henry Cabot Lodge, the former United States Ambassador in Saigon and onetime chief delegate to the Paris peace talks, says he doubted the possibility of a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: Ottawa Demands Release Of Citizen Held by Hanoi
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press—The Canadian Government has demanded the immediate release by Hanoi of a Canadian farm expert held captive in North Vietnam since 1968, the department of External Affairs said today.

headline: Poll Majority Feel President Achieved Peace With Honor
lead_paragraph: A majority of Americans agree with President Nixon that the United States is achieving “peace with honor” in Vietnam, according to a special nationwide Gallup poll conducted last Thursday — two days after Mr. Nixon's announcement of a settlement.

headline: Military
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29—The Department of Defense expects to spend $79‐billion next year, an increase of $4.2‐billion over the current year's total, despite the cease‐fire in Vietnam.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of cease‐fire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as “scattered light activity” whose intensity was gradually diminishing. “The fighting is definitely on a downward trend,” a high‐ranking American official said, “more noticeably in some areas than in others. There are no major units fighting. Nothing decisive is happening.” [Page 1, Column 1.]

headline: NIXON OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CEASE‐FIRE
lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Jan. 29 — The White House said today that it was not surprised that fighting was continuing in South Vietnam and expressed optimism that the cease‐fire would be scrupulously adhered to.

headline: Four‐Nation Truce Group Holds Its First Meeting
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29—The new four‐nation international control commission held its first meeting this morning and discovered that for the time being the organization was paralyzed.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: No Kiss, No Prayer
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — Went downtown the night the war ended wearing a peppermint‐striped, icecream‐cone‐shaped party hat and carrying a genuine Klaxon noisemaker and looking for pretty girls to hug and kiss in deliriums of joyous celebration, as the fancier newspapers used to say in the better old days.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: Saigon Troops Selectively Ignore Truce
lead_paragraph: CAM LONG, South Vietnam, Jan. 29 — South Vietnamese forces were openly ignoring the cease‐fire agreement in the area northwest of Saigon today, but on a relatively small scale and selectively.
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: Truce Holds Little Hope For a Village in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: TRUNG LAP, South Vietnam, Jan. 18 — Life in this village has been like a nightmare for its people during the war, They do not seem likely to fare much better after a cease‐fire.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Truce but No Truce . . .
lead_paragraph: The Vietnam tragedy pursues its course. Casualty rolls, American and Vietnamese, cannot yet be closed after all. Political machinery for cease‐fire supervision, so intri cately elaborated in advance, seems clogged with feuds over credentials, landing permits and protocol. The gov ernments say cease‐fire but the fighting sputters on.

headline: Base on Coast Prepares For Arrival of P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Jan. 30—For the re turning prisoners of war, the first glimpse of North Amer ica will be the headlands connected by the bridge across the Golden Gate, with the lights and towers of San Francisco behind.
author: By Wallace Turner Special to The New York Times

headline: Ants, Men and H‐Bombs
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the Vietnam war— at least its international phase—and in advance of the second SALT agreement and Mutual and Balanced Force Reduc tions, it is interesting if not heartening to examine previous efforts to limit the means by which men kill each other.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: SIHANOUK IS VISITING HANOI TO MARK TET
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 30 (Agence France‐Presse) — Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodion head of state, flew in here today from Peking for a week‐long visit.

headline: VIETNAM COMBAT STEADILY EBBING
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31—The level of fighting in Vietnam dropped substantially yesterday and to day and American analysts said the post‐cease‐fire combat was “slowly dying out.”
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Cubans Mark Cease‐Fire By Burning Effigy of Nixon
lead_paragraph: HAVANA, Jan. 30 (Reuters) — Cuban students last night burned a huge effigy of Presi dent Nixon at the end of a day of celebration marking the Viet nam cease‐fire.

headline: A Marine Returns From the Officially Dead
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — A marine private who was be lieved to have been killed in the battle of Khe Sanh in 1968 and buried in a military cemetery in St. Louis has turned up alive as a prisoner of war held by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Supervision of Cease‐Fire Remains Stalled by a Dispute in Military Commission
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31—Efforts to begin supervising the Viet nam cease‐fire remained blocked yesterday as the Four‐Party Joint Military Commission con tinued to be embroiled in a dis pute over how to hold its first formal session.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: L.I. Marine Listed as A.W.O.L.  Is Returning as Prisoner of War
lead_paragraph: BRENTWOOD, L. I., Jan. 30 —A Long Island Marine sched uled to be returned from a North Vietnamese prison camp to face possible charges of de sertion will be treated—at least for the time being—the same as any other repatriated P.O.W.
author: By David A. Andelman Special to The New York Times

headline: South Korea Hails Returning Soldiers As Pullout Is Begun
lead_paragraph: SUWON, South Korea, Jan. 30 — The first contingent of South Korean troops with drawn from Vietnam after the cease‐fire returned home today to a heroes’ welcome.

headline: BREZHNEV HAILS VIETNAM ACCORD AS TURNING POINT
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 30 — Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist leader, today hailed the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have a positive ef fect on Soviet‐American rela tions but also could influence settlements in world trouble spots such as the Middle East.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: What War Has Meant to Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30—What did more than a decade of war accomplish for South Vietnam?
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Last November the Mayor's Com mittee on Executive and Judicial Com pensation, composed of six distin guished business executives and pro fessional men, recommended what it termed a “modest” increase of $2,500 in the salaries of the 257 judges of the New York City Civil, Criminal and Family Courts—an increase well with in the then existing Federal Pay Board limits.
author: Bernard Botein New York, Jan. 25, 1973;

headline: A Marine Returns From the Officially Dead
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — A marine private who was be lieved to have been killed in the battle of Khe Sanh in 1968 and buried in a military cemetery in St. Louis has turned up alive as a prisoner of war held by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETNAM COMBAT STEADILY EBBING
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31—The level of fighting in Vietnam dropped substantially yesterday and to day and American analysts said that post‐cease‐fire combat was “slowly dying out.”
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: BREZHNEV HAILS VIETNAM ACCORD AS TURNING POINT
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 30 — Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist leader, today hailed the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have a positive ef fect on Soviet‐American rela tions but also could influence, settlements in world trouble spots such as the Middle East.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Continued Growth in Tie With Soviet Is Expected
