lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30— Nixon Administration officials believe that a more rapid de velopment of relations with China may turn out to be one of the major “dividends” for Washington from last week's Vietnam settlement.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Civilian P.O.W.'s Get Help if They Are Silent
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philip pines, Jan. 30—Returning Amer ican civilian prisoners of war will be given the same medical examinations and treatment that returning soldiers receive, but they will be ejected from the program if they make pub lic statements, a State Depart ment spokesman said here to day.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: 90,000 Prisoners
lead_paragraph: The eagerness with which Americans anticipate the release of 555 prisoners of war in the wake of the Vietnam cease‐fire makes it easier to understand the growing impatience in Pakistan over the continued detention of some 90,000 Pakistani war prisoners in India more than a year after the conclusion of hostilities on the Indian subcontinent.

headline: Excerpts From the Brezhnev Address
lead_paragraph: Following, as distrubuted in English by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, are ex cerpts from a speech deliv ered yesterday by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party chief, at a dinner in honor of the North Viet namese negotiators in Paris:

headline: A BRITISH LABORITE EXPECTED IN HANOI
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 30 (Agence France‐Presse) — James Callaghan, former Brit ish Home Secretary and Chan cellor of the Exchequer, is to visit Hanoi next month, an in formed Western source here said today.

headline: Reconstruction Days
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J.—Perhaps for the very first time after any major war the factual and technical groundwork for an immediate start on the task of reconstruction and development has already been prepared in advance of the end of a war. In published form, the study is known as “The Postwar Development of the Republic of Viet nam.” (1970)
author: By David E. Lilienthal

headline: Agnew, in Saigon, Affirms U.S. Support
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnanm, Wednesday, Jan. 31 — Vice President Agnew arrived in Saigon yesterday for discus sions with President Nguyen Van Thieu on postwar relations between the United States and South Vietnam.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Kin of Those Still Missing Still Wait
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif., Jan. 31—For Bernice Smith, the waiting continues.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: NEWS TALK IS HELD
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31—President Nixon announced today that he would send Henry A. Kissinger to Hanoi on Feb. 10 for three days in an effort to make the peace in Vietnam more secure and lay the groundwork for reconstruction of Southeast Asia.
author: By John Herders Special to The New York Times

headline: Military Mail to Vietnam Will Be Halted March 1
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)—The Postal Service announced today that it would refuse as of March 1 all personal letters mailed to military personnel in Vietnam.

headline: European Conferences: A Brief Guide
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. Jan. 31—It has been a time of unusual diplomatic activity, not only in conjunction with the Vietnam cease‐fire but also on problems involving many European countries. What follows is a summary of, the major negotiations currently involving the United States.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: P.O.W.'s Greeters Told to De‐emphasize the Military
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Jan. 31—He will come from a quiet, slowmotion world. There, in the endless hours, days; years, sounds were probably events and changes in temperature and humidity were experiences. There, food, clothing and shelter were basic, drab and bare. Language was simple.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: All Freed P.O.W.'s to Get Lifetime Baseball Pass
lead_paragraph: Each prisoner of war returning from Indochina will receive a gold‐plated lifetime pass good for any professional baseball game, Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, announced yesterday.

headline: Hanoi Aide Confers in Soviet On Cease‐Fire Situation
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (AP) —North Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Duy Trinn, conferred today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, on the cease‐fire situation in South Vietnam and then left for home, Tass reiported.

headline: The North Vietnamese Prepare For First Peaceful Tet in Years
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 31 (Agence France‐Presse)—Fire crackers sputtered in the streets of Hanoi far into last night as the nation prepared for its first peacetime Tet, or Lunar New Year, in years.

headline: Nixon to 1976 Candidates: Don't Be Eager Too Soon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31—Richard Nixon, who has been running for office for 26 years with — as he said — “mixed results,” offered some advice today to candidates for the Presidency in 1976: Don't be too eager.
author: By Clifton Daniel Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon, Restating Opposition to Amnesty, Stresses Punishment
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31—President Nixon reiterated today his opposition to amnesty for those who refused to serve in the military in the Vietnam war. Instead, he stressed the need for criminal penalties and said, “We cannot provide forgiveness for them.”
author: By Anthony Ripley Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. LOSES TWO F‐4'S IN GULF OFF DA NANG
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, Jan. 31 (UPI)—The commander of United States forces in the Pacific announced that two F‐4 jet fighters crashed in the. Gulf of Tonkin off Vietnam today during a routine patrol mission.

headline: Nixon Acknowledges American Jailed in China Is C. I. A. Agent
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 —When John T. Downey was a Yale senior in 1951, a classmate later recalled, a Central Intelligence Agency recruiter visited the campus.
author: By Eric Pace Special to The New York Times

headline: North Vietnamese Who Hold the Angkor Temples Show No Sign of Making Peace
lead_paragraph: SIEMREAB, Cambodia, Jan. 31—A tough North Vietnamese regiment in control of the vast stone temples, palaces and pavilions of the ancient city of Angkor shows no signs of making peace, yet it is clearly having trouble keeping its Cambodian collaborators in the same frame of mind.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Commissions to Monitor the Vietnam Cease‐Fire Make First Official Contact
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Thursday, Feb. 1—The two commissions that are to monifor the Vietnam cease‐fire had their first official contact yesterday, but there was still no indication when either might actually begin its work in the countryside.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Richardson Orders a Defense‐Cut Study
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 — Mr. Richardson, who took office yesterday, said at a news conference that he did not want to hold out the prospect of “massive” reductions. But he did say that the cessation of American combat activities in Vietnam should make some savings possible.
author: By William BeecherSpecial to The New York Times

headline: FIGHTING GOES ON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 1—Fighting continued to sputter and flare in South Vietnam yesterday as the cease‐fire went into its fifth day.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: FIGHTING GOES ON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 1—Fighting continued to sputter and flare in South Vietnam yesterday as the cease‐fire went into its fifth day.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: ROOM PREPARED FOR SON'S RETURN
lead_paragraph: Over the last five years and nine months—the time that has passed since her only son, Lieut. Comdr. Read B. Mecleary, was shot down in North Vietnam and captured — Mrs. Peyton Mecleary has come to treasure each small contact she has had with him and with people who knew him and with those who have reached out to her in kindness and support.

headline: Movements of Newsmen Being Curbed by Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 — The South Vietnamese armed forces and police have sharply restricted the movement of foreign newsmen since the cease‐fire went into effect on Sunday and have threatened some of them at gunpoint.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Says It Doesn't Plan Civilian P.O.W Penalties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) — Civilian prisoners of war will not be penalized with loss of military medical treatment if they talk to newsmen after their release by the Communists, the State Department said today.

headline: Vietnam: A Soviet View
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW—The agreement on ending the war which opens the way to restoration of peace in Vietnam and the whole of Indochina has been received in the Soviet Union, as in the world, with great satisfaction.
author: By Spartak Beglov

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31—Following is the White House transcript of President Nixon's news confernee at the White House today:

headline: HANOI RAIDS UPHELD BY ALEXIS JOHNSON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3I—U. Alexis Johnson, President Nixon's nominee to replace Gerard C. Smith as the chief American negotiator at the talks with the Soviet Union on limitation of strategic arms, said today that he believed the results of the bombing of Hanoi last month were “good” because they helped “in bringing about an agreement” to end the war.

headline: Coast Guard Quits Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (UPI)—The last seven men of the United States Coast Guard contingent in Vietnam have gone home, the United States command said today, leaving American strength at about 21,000.

headline: Amid Cease‐Fire Battles, Peasants Remain Stoical
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31—The Vietnamese are a remarkable and stoical people.
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: NEWS TALK IS HELD
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31—President Nixon announced today that he would send Henry A. Kissinger to Hanoi on Feb. 10 for three days in an effort to make the peace in Vietnam more secure and lay the groundwork for reconstruction of Southeast Asia.
author: By John Herbers Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Fliers, Captured by Foe Last Fall, Become Fathers
lead_paragraph: GOLDSBORO, N. C., Jan. 31 (AP) — When Capt. John H. Alpers Jr. and Capt. Brian M. Ratzlaff of the Air Force are released from North Vietnamese prisoner‐of‐war camps, they will learn they became fathers four days after a cease‐fire went into effect.

headline: LAOS P.O.W. LIST SNOWS 9 FROM U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 —North Vietnam turned over to the United States in Paris today the names of nine American prisoners — seven servicemen and two civilians—held by Communist forces in Laos. The list also included the name of a Canadian civilian.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: The President's Tough Line
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 —A lot of people around here have been wondering about President Nixon's mood as he goes into his second term, and now we have a few hints from the President himself. The man is fighting mad. He has his second term and his settlement in Vietnam, and he has come out of his struggles with all his grievances intact. If anything, he is more combative and energetic than ever before, and he seems determined to reform everything and everybody but himself.
author: By James Reston

headline: AGNEW, ON A VISIT, ASSURES LON NOL
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 1—Vice President Agnew, paying a five‐hour visit, assured Cambodia today of continued U. S. support.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Bars Newsmen From Tan Son Rat Base
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1— South Vietnamese military officials informed journalists today that their press credentials were no longer valid for entry to Tan Son Nhat air base.

headline: Vietcong General Joins Military Team in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 2—The chief of the Vietcong delegation to the joint military commission, who is the second highest‐ranking member of the Communist apparatus in South Vietnam, arrived In Saigon yesterday aboard a United States Army helicopter after being picked up in a Communist‐held town near the Cambodian border.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: KISSINGER TO SEEK ‘NORMALIZATION’ IN VISIT TO HANOI
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 —Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that during his mission to Hanoi next week he would explore ways of moving relations between the United States and North Vietnam “from hostility toward normalization.”
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Marked Decrease’ Noted In South Vietnam Fighting
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 2—With the Vietnam cease‐fire in its sixth day, American analysts today reported “a marked decrease” in fighting and said that the situation was approaching “a fairly manageable level.”
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Chou Urges U.S. to Halt Action in All Indochina
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Feb. 1 — Premier Chou En‐lai last night hailed the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement as a great victory for China's Vietnamese allies, and called upon Washington and Saigon to refrain from any acts of “procrastination, expansion and sabotage” that could undermine it.
author: By John Burns The Globe and Mall, Toronto

headline: Vietcong General Joins Military Team in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 2—The chief of the Vietcong delegation to the joint military commission, Lieut. Gen. Tran Van Tra, arrived in Saigon yesterday aboard a United States Army helicopter after being picked up in a Communist‐held town near the Cambodian border.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Marked Decrease’ Noted In South Vietnam Fighting
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 2—With the Vietnam cease‐fire in its sixth day, American analysts today reported “a marked decrease” in fighting and said that the situation was approaching “a fairly manageable level.”
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: Ragtime ‘Much Ado’ on Tonight
lead_paragraph: After an extraordinary lineup of news specials last night—interviews with Henry A. Kissinger, the late Lyndon B. Johnson and South Vietnam's President Thieu—the Columbia Broadcasting System is tonight turning over its three hours of prime time, from 8 to 11, to Shakespeare's “Much Ado About Nothing.”
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: LONDON PAPER SAYS CHINA HELD P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 1 — Victor Louis, the Soviet citizen who is Moscow's correspondent of The London Evening News, said in a dispatch today that American prisoners of war captured in Vietnam “have been held in secret maximum security camps in China.”

headline: LAOS P.O.W. LIST SHOWS 9 FROM U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 —North Vietnam turned over to the United States in Paris today the names of nine American prisoners — seven servicemen and two civilians—held by Communist forces in Laos. The list also included the name of a Canadian civilian.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Hears War Called a ‘Sin’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1—President Nixon, the Rev. Billy Graham and three Russian atheists were among the more than 3,000 people who attended the 21st National Prayer Breakfast here today and heard a longtime foe of the Vietnam war call it “a sin that has scarred the national soul.”
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am sorry that there was such little public notice of Secretary John A. Volpe's glorious exit from the Department of Transportation—his rejection of a major interstate highway route through an urban park.

headline: Excerpts From Interview in Which Kissinger Discussed U.S. Policy in Indochina
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a transcript of an interview between Marvin Kalb of the Columbia Broadcasting System and Henry A. Kissinger in Washington, as televised last night and recorded by The New York Times:

headline: 3 Concerns Going to Burlington; Move Will Help to Ease Job Lack
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Feb. 1—Three companies with an employment potential of 300 people leased a three‐story brick building today in this city, which just lost 600 jobs because the Vietnam ceasefire closed the Army's Burlington ammunition plant.

headline: U.S Reports 4 Deaths Put War Toll at 45,941
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1—Four Americans were killed during the week that ended with the start of the Vietnam cease‐fire last Sunday, the United States military command said today.

headline: Nixon, Greeting Heath, Says that U.S. Can Now Focus on European Policies
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 —President President Nixon welcomed Prime Minister Heath of Britain to the White House today and said that because of the Vietnam settlement the United States could now concentrate on its relations with Europe —which he called “the cornerstone of American policy.”

headline: KISSINGER TO SEEK ‘NORMALIZATION’ IN VISIT TO HANOI
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. I —Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that during his mission to Hanoi next week he would explore ways of moving relations between the United States and North Vietnam “from hostility toward normalization.”
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Australia Takes the First Steps Toward Recognition of Hanoi
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 1—Australia, whose troops helped to fight Communist insurgency in South Vietnam for more than 10 years, has instituted steps toward diplomatic relations with Hanoi.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: Journeys for Healing
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's decision to dispatch Henry Kissinger to Hanoi late next week is a beneficial omen for an uncertain peace.

headline: Peking Leader ship Greets Hanoi Aides At Cease‐Fire Rally
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Feb. 2 (Reuters)—Almost the entire Chinese leadership led 10,000 people in a mass rally in Peking today to celebrate the Vietnam ceasefire.

headline: A Diplomat's Hail to His Chief
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—“Peace that heals.” The phrase Seemed only a distant dream when President Nixon first uttered it in his Inaugural Address four years ago. But now, three days into his second term, the President has repeated the appealing words and delivered the results to back them up.
author: By Henry Cabot Lodge

headline: Arms Aid for Cambodia and Laos Debated in Capital
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2—A disagreement has reportedly broken out within the Nixon Administration over whether the recently concluded agreement for a cease‐fire in Vietnam allows the United States to continue military aid to Laos and Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Is Saki to Move Troops Out of Cambodia Combat Zones
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 2—Some movement of Vietnamese Communist troops out of battle areas was reported here today, but there was difference of opinion as to its significance.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: A Post‐Vietnam Era
lead_paragraph: In this country and abroad many words have been spoken in recent years about the glowing prospects peaceful great‐power coexistence in the world; of the 1970's, if only the irritant of the Vietnam war could be removed. Now that the moment is at hand, all the diplomatic projects now under way or about to be launched assume a special importance.

headline: Thieu Acts to Open Talks With Vietcong Next Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 3—President Nguyen Van Thieu announced today.that he had ordered a senior diplomat, to begin talks in Paris with the Vietcong on the political future of South Vietnam.
author: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU ORDERS AIDE TO MEET VIETCONG
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 3—President Nguyen Van Thieu announced to day that he had ordered a sen for diplomat to begin talks in Paris with the Vietcong on the political future of South Vietnam.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon and Heath Conclude Talks and Return to Capital
lead_paragraph: CAMP DAVID, Md., Feb. 2 (UPI) — President Nixon and Prime Minister Heath of Britain concluded nine hours of talks on matters ranging from trade and economics to the Vietnam peace settlement.

headline: ARMS TO CAMBODIA AND LAOS DEBATED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2—A disagreement has reportedly broken out within the Nixon Administration over whether the recently concluded agreement for a cease‐fire in Vietnam allows the United States to continue military aid to Laos and Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Truce Supervisors Vote To Put Inspectors in Field
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 3—After several days of fruitless debate, the International Commission of Control and Supervision voted this morning to send out its regional inspection teams on Monday, Canadian officials said, thus setting up the first machinery for actually monitoring the Vietnam cease‐fire.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Text of the President's Message on State of Union
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)—Following is the text of President Nixon's State of the Union Message sent to Congress today:

headline: St. Albans Hospital Is Prepared To Aid P.O.W's From Vietnam
lead_paragraph: No one at the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens knows exactly when the prisoners of war will arrive or how many will be processed there, but the staff of the 607‐bed hospital, now only half full, is ready and waiting. They are waiting not only for the returning Vietnam servicemen but also for their families who will arrive there for reunions.
author: By Nancy Hicks

headline: Kissinger To Hanoi
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Once again, President Nixon's ambassador extraordinary was preparing for another special conference. The site; Hanoi. The time: Feb. 10, to 13. The purpose: to begin a dialogue, that, could move relations with North Vietnam, “from hostility towards normalization.”
author: Bernard Gwertzman

headline: Chaotic Cambodia
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH—The outlook for a cease‐fire in Cambodia is becoming more optimistic. Sporadic military clashes continue, but on a small scale, and there are signs that the North Vietnamese‐Vietcong component of the anti‐Government forces is reducing its activity and may be pulling away from areas of combat.
author: Tillman Durdin

headline: Nixon Budget Reflects Use of 3 Tactical Rules
lead_paragraph: The first budget of the second Nixon Administration marks the end of an era that began with the pursuit of both guns and butter, the Vietnam war and the war on poverty, and ended with excessive inflation and excessive unemployment — and with the collapse of the international monetary system to boot.
author: By Michael E. Levy

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The offer by United Nations Secretary General Waldheim to mount a strictly humanitarian reconstruction operation in Vietnam without any discrimination is a news item which is most timely and most welcome.

headline: Other News From Indochina
lead_paragraph: TRUCE OBSERVERS Communist and allied delegates to the Joint Military Commission and members of the International Commission of Control and Supervision of the Vietnam cease‐fire met for the first time today in Saigon. Officials said that the international commission would start sending out field inspection teams tomorrow.

headline: 2 Cease‐Fire Control Units Hold First Saigon Meeting
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 4—Communist delegates to the Joint Military Commission appeared in downtown Saigon today for the first time to meet with members of the International Commission of Control and Supervision of the Vietnam cease‐fire.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: At the other end of the tunnel
lead_paragraph: When the war has ended and the road is open again, the same stars will course through the heavens. Then will I weep for the white bones heaped together in desolate graves of those who sought military honors for their leaders. —From a diary of an unknown North Vietnamese soldier, 1965.
author: By Fox Butterfield

headline: PROBLEMS CLOUD WHITLAM'S IMAGE
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 3—The new Labor Government of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam has run into severa image problems as it enters its third month in office, following a sweeping electoral victory Dec. 2 over the conservative coalition that had ruled for 23 years.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: Headliners
lead_paragraph: A Lady's Will
author: Robert W. Stock

headline: 2 Vietnamese Daughters Of African President Wed
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Feb. 3 (Agence France‐Presse)—The two halfVietnamese daughters of President Jean Mel Bokassa, both called Martine and both 18 years old, have married Central African husbands.

headline: Skepticism Pervades a California Suburb After Decade of Conflict in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 3—A decade of conflict in Vietnam has left a mark in this suburban community, as it has across America. Many people think and feel differently from what they ?? did. They ask questions, they reject assumptions, they doubt what they are told.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: Issue of Amnesty
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON‐Ice‐hard statements made during election campaigns have a way of melting in the glow of victory. But President Nixon made it clear last week that there would be no melting of his statements on the issue of amnesty for men who refused to serve during the Vietnam war.
author: Anthony Ripley

headline: For Some Deserters Canada Is Home; Other Exiles Hope to Return to U.S.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO, Jan. 30 — Alan Kazmer, a 31‐year‐old advertising copywriter with the McCann‐Erickson agency here, stared into a glass of beer as he pondered the news from the United States.
author: By William Borders Special to The New York Times

headline: The Cease‐Fire
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Shrouded in secrecy, the seven American helicopters flew into a Communist‐held town about 70 miles north of Saigon. The aircraft picked up three score uniformed men and returned to Saigon's Tan Son Nhut airport. Out of one helicopter stepped Lieut. Gen. Tran Van Tra, the chief Vietcong delegate to the four‐party. Joint Military Commission that is to help monitor the cease‐fire in South Vietnam.
author: Sylvan Fox

headline: Canada's Truce Mission Stirs Some Anxieties at Home
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Feb. 3—Canada's truce mission in Vietnam, now one week old, has stirred an embarrassing controversy here.
author: By Jay Walz Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETNAM FIGHTING AT A VIRTUAL HALT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 4 — Fighting in South Vietnam reportedly ground to a virtual halt yesterday, a week after the formal cease‐fire went into effect.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Action on Prisoners
lead_paragraph: For almost five years, a simple gravestone in a military cemetery in St. Louis has marked the mass grave of nine Marines, casualties of the battle of Khe Sanh in South Vietnam in February, 1968. The nine bodies were found after an American patrol was ambushed.

headline: Hopeful Brezhnev
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW—“New possibilities for easing tensions, for consolidating security and world peace open now. The political settlement in Vietnam can be expected to have a positive effect on relations among states involved in one way or another in events in Indochina. Moreover, this shows it is possible to find a peaceful and just solution of other conflicts, to liquidate the danger from existing hotbeds of war, above all in the Middle East....”
author: Hedrick Smith

headline: NIXON AIDES MOVE AGAINST WAR FOES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3—Now that a peace agreement in Vietnam has been reached, members of the Nixon Administration have undertaken to discredit the critics of the President's conduct of the war and of peace negotiations.
author: By John Berbers Special to The New York Times

headline: RELIEF FOR SAIGON TO BE STEPPED UP
lead_paragraph: The International Rescue Committee reports that it is planning to participate in major relief and rehabilitation efforts in South Vietnam.

headline: INSPECTION TEAMS SENT TO 7 SITES TO MONITOR TRUCE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 5—In the first major step toward monitoring the Vietnam cease‐fire, which began a week ago Sunday, the International Commission of Control and Supervision this morning dispatched seven regional teams around South Vietnam.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Pope Says Vietnam Truce Is Marred by Violations
lead_paragraph: ROME, Feb. 4 (Reuters) —Pope Paul VI said today that the Vietnam cease‐fire was full of violations and stressed the need for justice, brotherhood and universal peace.

headline: 2 Officers Accuse Herbert of War Crimes ‘Hoax’
lead_paragraph: An Army general and a colonel charged in a nationwide television broadcast last night that a “hoax” had been perpetrated by retired Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, a highly decorated veteran of the Korean and Vietnam wars, in his contention that he was removed from command because of his complaints about war crimes in Vietnam.
author: By Peter Kihss

headline: U.S. Bombs in Laos Again
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, Feb. 4 (AP)—The Pacific military command reported that United States aircraft, including B‐52 bombers, continued operations over Laos today at the request of the Laotian Government. No details of the bombing were disclosed. The operations have continued daily since the Vietnam ceasefire began.

headline: Wives Waiting for P.O.W.'s With Hope and Anxiety
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 4—Sybil Stockdale bought a new Persian rug last year on her 25th wedding anniversary, but she has not put it down yet. She is waiting for her husband, Capt. James Bond Stockdale, who has been a prisoner in North Vietnam for almost eight years.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: P. O.W. CONDUCT BARRED AS TOPIC
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 4—Military sources said today that military escorts have been told to change the subject tactfully if a returning American prisoner of war begins discussing possible violations of the military code he might have committed in captivity.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Wives Waiting for P.O.W.'s With Hope and Anxiety
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 4—Sybil Stockdale bought a new Persian rug last year on her 25th wedding anniversary, but she has not put it down yet. She is waiting for her husband, Capt. James Bond Stockdale, who has been a prisoner in North Vietnam for almost eight years.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Reduced Pare for the Elderly

headline: Cease‐Fire Violations Said to Be Minor
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Monday, Feb. 5—Only isolated minor incidents broke the truce in South Vietnam yesterday as the cease‐fire moved into its second week.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Peace With Charity
lead_paragraph: President Nixon dispatched Henry Kissinger to Hanoi with a commendable mission to advance the cause reconciliation. Yet, at the same time, Mr. Nixon closed his heart and mind to pleas for similar acts of reconciliation toward his own country's draft resisters and antiwar exiles.

headline: Past And Future
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 4—Mr. Kissinger is right. It would be hard to find any American who from the beginning took a consistent, principled position on Vietnam. There are not many claimants for the holiness award.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: GAINS REPORTED AS TRUCE CHIEFS CONFER IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 5—An official spokesman said yesterday that the meeting in Saigon between the heads of the two peacekeeping commissions was “one of the most constructive steps” accomplished in a week. The commissioners met earlier in the day.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I.'s Are Leaving Vietnam for ‘the World’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 — They had been marking time, waiting for the cease‐fire. But now the last G.I.'s in Vietnam are moving out, most of them heading back to “the world,” as they call home.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Job for the U.N.
lead_paragraph: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's offer of a United Nations relief and reconstruction program “to all the peoples of Vietnam without discrimination” is one that should be taken up with alacrity by all sides, especially the United States.

headline: Laborites to Visit Vietnam
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 4 (UPI)—A British Labor party delegation will leave Thursday on a factfinding tour of North Vietnam and South Vietnam, a party spokesman said today.

headline: Cambodia Held Sure of U.S. Air Support
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 5 — An authoritative Cambodian source said today that the United States had assured this county that it would resume bombing in Cambodia if the North Vietnamese troops resumed offensive operations against Government troops.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON'S POPULARITY FOUND AT HIGH POINT
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's popularity rating reached 68 per cent, matching his previous high, point, following the announcement of the peace settlement in Vietnam, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

headline: SAIGON BYPASSES ACCORD IN FREEING MANY PRISONERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5—The Saigon Government has reportedly released thousands of military and civilian prisoners in the last few days, turning them loose on their own despite provisions of the Paris cease‐fire accord requiring that they be turned over to North Vietnam or the Vietcong.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon and Vietcong Aides Hold First Paris Meeting
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 5 — Delegates from the Saigon Government and the Vietcong met alone together here today for the first time. Their purpose was to prepare for the South Vietnamese political negotiations provided in the cease‐fire agreements. The negotiations are to test whether the hostile sides can eventually reach a nonviolent settlement to their generation‐long dispute.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. DEFENDS ARMS TO LAOS, CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5—The State Department said today that it was clearly understood by North Vietnam that the United. States could continue military aid to Laos and Cambodia under the agreement for a cease‐fire in Vietnam.

headline: CEASE‐FIRE UNITS TAKE THEIR POSTS
lead_paragraph: MY THO, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 6—International peace‐keeping teams fanned out across South Vietnam yesterday, but had not yet begun their work of monitoring violations of the cease‐fire pact.
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: NEWSMEN BLOCKED AT TRUCE‐UNIT SITES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam,: Feb. 5 (UPI—Attempts by newsmen to cover the first deployment of Vietnam truce inspectors were blocked at at least three of the sites, where the cease‐fire teams arrived today.

headline: Amnesty Strategy Parley Set for Paris
lead_paragraph: The drive for total amnesty for all war resisters will take a new dimension in Paris from Feb. 19 to 22, when three groups hall a strategy conference for exiles and their supporters.
author: By George Vecsey

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Jap. 13 Op‐Ed article entitled “The Conflict Over the Delaney Clause” requires clarification of the basic issue.

headline: Last American Killed Before the Truce Is Buried in Arlington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5—The Army buried one of its own today, Bill Nolde.
author: By Douglas E. Kneeland Special to The New York Times

headline: Canadian Named Chairman Of Vietnam Truce Group
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 (Reuters)—Michel Gauvin of Canada today was named chairman of the International Commission of Control and Supervision, the four‐nation organization charged with policing the Vietnam cease‐fire.

headline: The Nobel Prize Isn't Worth It
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5—The interesting thing about President Nixon's nomination to receive the Nobel Peace Prize is that he did not intervene to stop his admirers from entering his name in this unhappy competition.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: After War and Cease‐Fire, the South Vietnamese Communist Groups Remain a Mystery
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5—One of the mysteries of the Vietnam war has been the other side, those South Vietnamese Communists and nationalists who—with the support of North Vietnam—have battled the Saigon Government and the United States to a standstill.
author: By Seymour M. Hersh Special to The New York Times

headline: CEASE‐FIRE UNITS TAKE THEIR POSTS
lead_paragraph: MY THO, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 6—International peace‐keeping teams fanned out across South Vietnam yesterday, but had not yet begun their work of monitoring violations of the cease‐fire accord.
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Experts Begin Haiphong Sessions On Clearing Mines
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) —A team of United States Navy demolition experts headed by Rear Adm. Brian McCauley met in Haiphong today with the city harbormaster and other North Vietnamese officials to discuss plans for clearing away American mines and reopening the port the Pentagon reported.

headline: SAIGON BYPASSES ACCORD IN FREEING MANY PRISONERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5—The Saigon Government has reportedly released thousands of military, and civilian prison ers in the last few days, turn ing them loose on their own despite provisions of the Paris cease‐fire accord requiring that they be turned over to North Vietnam or the Vietcong.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Minesweepers Begin Preparatory Work Off Haiphong
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6—The Defense Department announced today that four United States Navy minesweepers had been ordered to begin clearing an anchorage on the approaches to Haiphong Harbor as a preliminary step toward destroying hundreds of mines that have blocked North Vietnamese ports for nine months.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Fleet's Role Seen Unchanged
lead_paragraph: MANILA, Feb. 6 —The commander of the Seventh Fleet said today that the role of the fleet would not change basically despite the Vietnam cease‐fire. “It will maintain the balance of power,” said the fleet commander, Vice Adm. James L. Holloway 3d, in a talk with the press on the guidedmissile cruiser Oklahoma City, which is visiting here.

headline: Hanoi May Release P.O.W.'s Saturday
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 7 —The first United States prisoners of war May be released on Saturday In Hanoi, the chairman of the International Commission of Control and Supervision said yesterday.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: The Peace Conference
lead_paragraph: Eight years to the day after the United States opened its devastating bombardment of North Vietnam, the warring parties have announced agreement to convene the Vietnam peace conference. Starting Feb. 26 in Paris, diplomats of the Soviet Union, China and the United States will sit down with representatives of the Vietnamese combatants, plus Britain, France and the four nations supervising the cease‐fire. This diplomatic assemblage will stand as the first test of great‐power responsibility in the post‐Vietnam war era.

headline: Vietnam's Joy in Victory
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Recently I met with Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh. My only disappointment was that every American could not share in the joy of Vietnam's victory. By any standards, it is incredible.
author: By Rennie Davis

headline: A Debt Of Honor
lead_paragraph: After the return of the prisoners from Vietnam, after all the consoling ceremonies at the White House, and the family reunions and tears on television, the reality for the prisoners coining home at last will begin in private. When they come home from Vietnam, what will they find?
author: By James Reston

headline: Washington: Some Optimism But No Plan for an Initiative
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6—Nixon Administration officials believe that the prospects for resolving the current “no‐war no‐peace” situation in the Middle East have improved with the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement, but for the moment they plan no major new initiative to bring the Arabs and Israelis closer together. As King Hussein of Jordan begins his visit to Washington, officials say that although President Nixon has declared that the Middle. East will get “a very high priority” this year, the White House—preoccupied with Indochina—has not yet had time to focus its full attention on that part of the world.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Pension Reform Bill: A ‘Sham’

headline: U.S. STEPPING UP ATTEMPT TO GAIN LAOS CEASE‐FIRE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6—The White House today announced a further effort to achieve cease‐fire in Laos and plans for an international conference that will try to solidify last month's Vietnam cease‐fire.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S STEPPING UP ATTEMPT TO GAIN LAOS CEASE‐FIRE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6—The White House today announced a further effort to achieve a cease‐fire in Laos and plans for an international conference that will try to solidify last month's Vietnam cease‐fire.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: MRS. GANDHI HITS U.S. POLICY IN ASIA
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Feb. 6—Prime Minister Indira Gandhi bitterly attacked American policy in Asia today, despite quiet diplomatic efforts in recent weeks to soothe the strained and chilly relations between India and the United States.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: Premier in Hanoi Insists on the Ultimate Reunification of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The following dispatch, distributed by The. Associated Press, 4 by Louise Hickman Lione of The Philadelphia Inquirer, who has just completed a visit to Hanoi. Transmission was delayed bedtime of review by the North Vietnamese.

headline: U.S. Forces Leaving At Rate of 400 a Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 (UPI) — American troops are leaving South Vietnam at a rate of more than 400 a day, the United States command said today. There were 19,500 in the country as of Sunday, the lowest number since September, 1964.

headline: Australia to Begin Negotiations To Establish Ties With Hanoi
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 6—Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced today that Australia plans to begin negotiations for establishment of diplomatic relations with North Vietnam next week.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: Some Air Force P.O.W.'s Will Receive $25,000 to $100,000 in Savings Accounts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6—Many of the prisoners of war, upon their release, will find several thousand dollars awaiting them in pay, savings and bonuses that accumulated while they were in captivity.

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: Pentagon sources said yesterday that Communist forces in South Vietnam would release 27 American prisoners of war on Sunday. [Page 1, Column 1.]

headline: U.S. REPORTS RAIDS IN LAOS STILL GO ON
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, Feb. 7 (UPI)—The United States Pacific forces command reported today that American aircraft conducted bombing missions over Laos for the 11th straight day since the start of the Vietnam ceasefire.

headline: Sister of P.O.W. Thinks He Will Face a ‘Shock’
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb, 7 —When Lieut. Comdr. Everett Alvarez went away to war, he believed in his country, and the battles it was fighting in Southeast Asia. Soon he will be coming home, home to a family, and to many countrymen, who feel that his sacrifice of eight and one‐half years in a North Vietnamese prison camp was a waste of time.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: What is especially disturbing about President Nixon's special counsel Charles Colson's Jan. 30 Op‐Ed article, “The Georgetown Blacking Factory,” is not the importance of the charges it makes—for they are as absurd as those Mr. Colson claims were made by his “adversaries”—but the care with which, he sought to set the record straight on a matter of colossal unimportance, except for propaganda purposes. President Nixon has gathered around him a large group of P. R. men to “get the record straight” who can only be described as amateur Josef Goebbelses.

headline: SUNDAY RELEASE OPEL'S EXPECTED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7—Pentagon sources said today that Communist forces plan to release 27 American prisoners of war Sunday from jungle camps in South Vietnam.

headline: Kissinger Leaves for Hanoi and Peking
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) —Henry A. Kissinger left today on a two‐week mission to Hanoi and Peking to begin repairing the damages of a decade of war in Indochina.

headline: OTTAWA IN SNIFF, RECOGNIZES HANOI
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Feb. 7—Canada today formally recognized the Government of North Vietnam, giving it “equal diplomatic status” with that of the South.

headline: As Truce Units Get Ready, Fighting Surges at Pleiku
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 8 — The two peace‐keeping commissions set pp by the Paris agreement spent another day dealing with preliminary procedural problems yesterday, while a sharp upsurge of fighting was reported from Pleiku in the Central Highlands.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: SUNDAY RELEASE OF G.I.'S EXPECTED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7—Pentagon sources said today that Communist forces plan to release 27 American prisoners of war Sunday from jungle camps in South Vietnam.

headline: Canada's Chief Delegate in Saigon
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Feb. 7—In the anxious weeks before the Vietnam cease‐fire the Canadian Government hesitated about taking a supervisory role that everyone knew would be long and troublesome.
author: By Jay Walz Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon and Vietcong Meet Again In Paris, Report Further Accord
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 7—Vietcong and Saigon Government representatives met here again today and reported further progress on arranging for the start of political negotiations in South Vietnam. They agreed to meet again Saturday.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: COMMUNISTS ATTACK 5 POSTS IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 7 (Reuters)—Communist troops renewed their attacks on Cambodian Government positions near the South Vietnamese border as heavy activity was reported on nearby infiltration trails, the military command said today.

headline: Congress Is Urged to Study U.S. Vietnam Involvement
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) —Senator Robert Dole, former Republican national chairman, called today for a Congressional investigation of the causes and origins of United States involvement in Vietnam.

headline: Administration Is Stung By Mrs. Gandhi's Charge
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7—The Nixon Administration respond. ed today with a combination of hock and irritation at stateents by Prime Minister Indira andhl of India yesterday that ere sharply critical of the United States.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Many Homeless, at Least Briefly, as Clashes Continue
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7—The small, widely scattered battles that have continued since the cease‐fire have driven some 200,000 people from their homes at least briefly, officials here said today.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Journey Into Peace
lead_paragraph: The current Asian journey of Henry Kissinger will lay the groundwork for the future role of the United States in Indochina and its relations with the emerging powers across the Pacific. In signaling just how low will be the American profile in postwar Asia, Mr. Kissinger's nuances will be as important as his overview—and his hosts in Hanoi, Vientiane and Peking are not exactly novices in sensing nuance.

headline: Village View: ‘It Is Only a Cease‐Fire’
lead_paragraph: LONG DINH, South Vietnam, Feb. 8—Mrs, Tran Thi Anh was harvesting her rice here today, winnowing the dry brown stalks to separate the grain, when the first artillery rounds began landing near her field.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor The President vs. Congress: Power of the Purse
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his press conference on Jan. 31, President Nixon was so incautious as to cite Harry Truman'S impounding of the funds appropriated for a 70‐group Air Force, of which Truman had decided that a 48‐group of war planes was adequate. As such; Mr. Nixon underlined inescapably the most decisive issue around which his impounding of funds and budgetary cuts for protection of the environment, for health, education; housing and welfare in favor of a $4.2‐billion, budget increase for the military will be vehemently opposed, especially in the fate of the end of the Vietnam war.
author: Eli Black

headline: House Panel Tells Rogers Aid to Hanoi Is Unpopular
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8—Secretary of State William P. Rogers was warned by members of a House committee today that the Nixon Administration's proposals to provide a postwar economic aid program to North Vietnam were encountering growing public opposition.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: NEWSMEN DETAINED AT SAIGON AIR BASE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 8 (UPI)—The Government detained 23 newsmen briefly today and seized their press cards wnen they tried to talk with North Vietnamese and Vietcong members of the Four‐Party Joint Military Commission.

headline: PILOT WHO BALKED GETS A DISCHARGE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 — A B‐52 pilot who refused to fly more bombing raids in Vietnam after 175 missions has been granted a discharge from the Air Force.
author: By Anthony Ripley Special to The New York Times

headline: House Panel Tells Rogers Aid to Hanoi Is Unpopular
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8—Secretary of State William P. Rogers was warned by members of a House committee today that the Nixon Administration's proposals to provide postwar economic aid program to North Vietnam were encountering growing public opposition.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Mayor Presses Members Of House for Urban Aid
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 —Mayor Lindsay appealed to the New York City Congressional delegation today to push for increased Federal domestic programs now that the nation's involvement in Vietnam was winding down.
author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘EDUCATION’ GIVEN ELLSBERG JURORS
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8—The jury in the Pentagon papers trial started today to get an “education” about the Vietnam war and also about documents that the Government contends contain military secrets.
author: By Martin Arnold Special to The New York Times

headline: Civilians Taking Over U. S. Task in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Feb. 8—Young diplomats and paunchy middle‐aged airplane mechanics are quietly replacing the professional soldiers who have been in the forefront of the United States establishment in South Vietnam for 10 years.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: PILOT WHO BALKED GETS A DISCHARGE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 — A B‐52 pilot who refused to fly more bombing raids in Vietnam after 175 missions has been granted a discharge from the Air Force, his civilian lawyer said today.
author: By Anthony Ripley Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON PARLEYS ARE DRAGGING ON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 9—Steps toward carrying out the terms of the agreement for a Vietnam ceasefire dragged yesterday, but there were a few signs of progress.
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: Metropolitan Briefs
lead_paragraph: A noon protest action yesterday by thousands of employes in 33 voluntary hospitals delayed lunch service to some of the institutions' 15,000 patients, but there was no major disruption of patient care, hospital officials said. Medical attendants, technicians and others among the more than 15,000 people on duty at the time gave up their lunch hours to protest the Federal Pay Board's rollback of an 8.3 per cent wage and benefit increase awarded for the 33,000 voluntary‐hospital employes last July. The increase had not been paid pending the board's ruling, which cut the increase to 5.5 per cent.

headline: Hospital Seeks Smooth P.O.W. Return
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 8—At the Naval Hospital here yesterday, a local garden club was hauling in a load of plants to decorate the rooms set aside for returning prisoners of war.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: Chinese Delegate Named
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Feb. 8 (Reuters)—Foreign Minister Chi Peng‐fei of China will attend the international conference on Vietnam starting in Paris Feb. 26, the Kyodo news agency reported today in a dispatch from Peking.

headline: Thieu Begins Talks With Other Groups; Election Step Seen
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9— A Government spokesman announced today that President Nguyen Van Thieu had begun a series of discussions with political and religious leaders, in what was regarded by some American officials as a first step in trying to unify non‐Communist elements in preparation for eventual elections open to Communist candidates.

headline: BOUNDARY LINES HINDERING TRUCE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9—The chairman of the new International Control Commission asserted today that an effective cease‐fire was being delayed because the Saigon Government and the Communists have been unable to agree on clear lines separating the territories they hold.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Mrs. Gandhi Implies Remarks Were Not Anti‐U.S.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Feb. 9—Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, seeking to smooth India's strained relations with the United States, suggested today that her recent remarks on Vietnam were not intended to offend any country.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: HANOI WILL FREE 115 U.S. CAPTIVES TOMORROW NIGHT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9—The Pentagon announced today that North Vietnam planned to release about 115 American prisoners of war in Hanoi sometime Sunday night, Eastern standard time, while 27 more prisoners would be turned over by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: PILOT IS PLANNING FIGHT ON DISCHARGE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietndin, Feb 9 (AP)—Capt. Michael J. Heck, the Young B‐52 pilot granted discharge from the Air Force for “other than, honorable” reasons after he had refused to fly A mission over North Vietnam on Dec. 26, said today that he was planning a legal appeal of that type of discharge.

headline: Professors As Makers Of Policy
lead_paragraph: CARBONDALE, Ill—Robert Cutler, architect of the developed National Security Council organization under President Eisenhower, was a Boston banker. Penetrating in understanding and precise in detail, he chaired the security council planning board with care and fairness, seeking agreed recommendations or, if these were not attainable, an exact presentation of diverse views for the benefit of the President. He was a cautious, deliberative man who weighed risks carefully; as bankers should be, he was a prudent man.
author: By Howard Trivers

headline: 1,200 G.I.'s Leave Vietnam; U.S. Forces Down to 18,600
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 (UPI)—A total of 1,200 American servicemen left South Vietnam this week, reducing United States strength there to 18,600 men, military spokesmen said today.

headline: BOUNDARY LINES HINDERING TRUCE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9—The chairman of the new International Control Commission asserted today that an effective cease‐fire was being delayed because the Saigon Government and the Communists have been unable to agree on clear lines separating the territories they hold.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: HANOI WILL FREE 115 U.S. CAPTIVES TOMORROW NIGHT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9—The Pentagon announced today that North Vietnam planned to release about 115 American prisoners of war in Hanoi sometime Sunday night, Eastern standard time, while 27 more prisoners would be turned over by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. ‘Escorts’ Await the Prisoners
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 9—A few days ago, Sgt. 1st Cl. Horace Purifoy and Sgt. 1st Cl. Robert L. Cutting of the Army walked over to the base uniform store to polish buttons and other brass belonging to two men they have never met but already know.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: P.O.W.'s Will Get the News, 1965 to 1971
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md., Feld. 9 —The first entry is the inauguration of President Johnson in January, 1965; the last, the June, 1971, Supreme Court decision on state aid to nonpublic schools. Packed into the pages between is a cram course in events‐that‐were‐current in the world outside the prisonerof‐war camps in Vietnam.
author: By Linda Charlton Special to The New York Times

headline: Secret Paris Pact on Laos And Cambodia Disclosed
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9—The United States and North Vietnam agreed secretly in their negotiations in Paris last month that a ban on foreign military activity in Laos and Cambodia would not take effect immediately, sources in the Nixon Administration reported today.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Kissinger Flies From Laos to Hanoi
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Saturday, Feb. 10—Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser for national security, left here today for Hanoi, saying that he expected his trip would “usher in an era of peace” for all of Indochina.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETCONG CHARGE ABUSE IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 10—The Vietcong charged today that the Communist military delegates who are in Saigon to help oversee the cease‐fire were being treated “shamefully.”
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Announces Names of 142 Prisoners to Be Freed Tomorrow
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) —The Pentagon announced today the names of the American military prisoners of war who are in the first group, scheduled to be released Sunday night, Eastern standard time, from Communist camps in North and South Vietnam.

headline: Making of Jets on Taiwan Reported Sought by U.S
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10—The Nixon Administration is reportedly preparing to withdraw 5,000 to 6,000 troops from Taiwan but, at the same time, is moving to enable the Nationalist Chinese Government there to become selfsufficient in modern jet fighters.
author: By William Beecher. Special to The New York Times

headline: They Are Different Men Now
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—Some have suffered captivity for only a few months, others for eight years . . some were injured, others escaped without a scratch ... some will slip back easily into their prewar lives, others will never fully recover.
author: Steven V. Roberts

headline: So Far, So Good
lead_paragraph: The success of the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement, Henry Kissinger said, “depends not only on its provisions, but also on the spirit in which it is implemented.” Now, after two weeks of truce, there is real progress, though more is needed.

headline: Agnew Briefs Nixon on His Asian Tour
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 10—Vice President Agnew reported to President Nixon today on his just‐concluded trip to Southeast Asia, saying that Asian leaders were interested hi the “attitude” of South Vietnam's President Nguyen Van Thieu.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Major Held Prisoner By Vietcong 9 Years
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)—Maj. Floyd J. Thompson of the Army, for nine years a captive of the Vietcong, has been held an enemy prisoner longer than any other American in all the wars of United States history.

headline: RACE ISSUE SPLITS NEW ZEALANDERS
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 10—Controversy over proposed visit of an all‐white South African rugby team to New Zealand is growing into a national crisis. Already it had divided this country more bitterly than at the height of demonstrations over participation in the Vietnam war.

headline: The Rough Road Back for P.OW's
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10—As the first American prisoners start their journey home tomorrow night, they will move from a world of silence to a world of noise, from slow motion to speed, from isolation to crowds, from idleness to activity and from the company of military men to the company of wives, children and friends.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: After the War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—It was not happening precisely according to the timetable laid down by the Paris accord, and there was some apparent tampering by the Saigon Government with the spirit if not the letter of the cease‐fire agree ment, but peace in South Vietnam seemed last week to be acquiring a momentum of its own. And the first batch of American prisoners of war was about to be released.
author: Sylvan Fox

headline: Asian Parley in India Ends In Consensus on Self‐Help
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Feb. 10 — An international assembly of more than 200 intellectuals, meeting here to discuss Asian problems, ended this week with the consensus that Asian countries should solve their problems themselves without outside help.

headline: NEWS BAN REPORTED WHEN 27 ARE FREED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 (UPI)—A spokesman for the Canadian delegation to the International Commission for Control and Supervision said today that plans for news coverage of the first prisone release in South Vietnam Monday had apparently been dropped.

headline: AFTER 2 WEEKS, PEACE IS ELUSIVE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10—Two weeks after a ceasefire officially went into effect, relatively small‐scale fighting was continuing over much of Vietnam and the machinery to detect and possibly deter the violations had not even begun to work.
author: By Charles Mohr Special to The New York Times

headline: NEWSMAN VISITS IN VIETCONG ZONE
lead_paragraph: IN A VIETCONG ZONE South Vietnam, Feb. 8 (Reuters —In 24 hours with the Viet cong I drank tea, shared meal, chatted about the West—and ran for cover with then when a South Vietnamese heli copter gunship sprayed a vil lage in a raid lasting more that half an hour.

headline: U.S Units in Philippines Poised for P.O.W. Airlift
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Phil—ippines, Feb. 10—The clocks on the wall inside the Joint Homecoming Reception Center Command Post read “Hanoi,” “Local,” “Hawaii,” “Wash. D.C.” and “Zulu”—the Air Force way of saying Greenwich mean time.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The tragedy of America's involvement in Vietnam is not that the U. S. chose to stand and fight against Communist, aggression, but that we chose to stand and fight so badly. Never have such self‐defeating restrictions been placed on the use of American military power.

headline: U. S. Aid Will Be Topic at Hanoi Talks But Issue ls Clouded With Uncertainty
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 —While the United States has a commitment to aid in the reconstruction of the four countries of Indochina, beyond that general pledge all is uncertainty.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: KISSINGER ARRIVE IN HANOI FOR TALK ON POSTWAR ROLES
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 10—Henry A. Kissinger arrived here today to discuss postwar United States relations with North Vietnam.

headline: P.O.W. Phone Calls Will End the Doubts For Area Families
lead_paragraph: The Gordon E. Bakers of Huntington, L. I., and the James P. Welshes of Winstead, Conn., along with scores of other American families, will stand by their telephones once more tomorrow—this time to hear a familiar voice confirm to them the end of a long and often agonizing wait.

headline: Last U.S. Fighting Unit In Vietnam Is Disbanded
lead_paragraph: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 (Reuters)—The last American fighting unit in South Vietnam was formally disbanded today.

headline: Saigon Ousts Its Top Man On the Truce Commission
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11—The Saigon Government has abruptly replaced the head of its delegation to the Four‐Party Joint Military Commission, a military spokesman said tonight.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Promoter Hits Snags On P.O.W. Vacations
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 11—Roger Chapin, who has raised More than $4.5‐million in public donations sover the last five years to demonstrate the American people's “heartfelt affection” for their fighting men, is encountering rough going in his latest enterprise: to give every homecoming prisoner of war a free vacation in Acapulo, Hawaii, the Virgin Islands or come other lush vacation spot.
author: By Everett R. Holles Special to The New York Times

headline: More Than an Armistice
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—In 1973, as in 1962 and 1954, warring parties in Indochina entered into military and political agreements to stop the fighting and move toward a stable peace. For the sake of the long‐suffering Vietnamese and other Indochinese people to whose tragic plight we have undeniably contributed and also in our own selfinterest, the United States should take all reasonable steps to reduce the likelihood of a resumption of war.
author: W. Averell Harriman

headline: AIRCRAFT LEAVE TO PICK UP P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Monday, Feb. 12—Operation Homecoming—the repatriation of American prisoners of the Vietnam war—began here today.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: After the Draft
lead_paragraph: President Nixon has achieved his objective of shifting the armed services from partial reliance on conscription to an all‐volunteer basis. He has also cut the size of the armed services from their Vietnam peak of 3.5 million persons to 2.3 million.

headline: Saigon Ousts Its Top Man On the Truce Commission
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11—The Saigon Government has abruptly replaced the head of its delegation to the Four‐Party Joint Military Commission, a military spokesman said tonight.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Nation Urged to Respect Privacy of Ex‐P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP) — President Nixon said today that Americans should respect the privacy of the returning prisoners of war.

headline: SNAG ON EXCHANGE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 12—The release of 27 Americans who were scheduled to be the first United States prisoners of war freed under the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement was delayed this morning, apparently because of a dispute over an exchange of Communist prisoners.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: AIRLIFT IS BEGUN
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Monday, Feb. 12—The repatriation of American prisoners of the Vietnam war began today.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Kissinger Talks in Hanoi Called ‘Serious’ by the White House
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 11 (Reuters) — Henry A. Kissinger met for six hours today with North Vietnamese Government officials for a second round of talks on American postwar relations with North Vietnam, the Western White House said.

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: The release of 27 Americans who were scheduled to be the first United States prisoners of war freed under the Vietnam ceasefire agreement was delayed this morning, apparently because of a dispute over an exchange of Communist prisoners. The release had been set for 8:30 A.M. Saigon time (7:30 P.M. Sunday, New York Times), but by midmorning it had not been made. [Page 1, Column 8.]

headline: RELEASE IN SOUTH RUNS INTO A SNAG
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 12—The release of 27 Americans who were scheduled to be the first United States prisoners of war freed under the Vietnam cease‐fire agreement was delayed this afternoon, apparently because of a dispute over an exchange of Communist prisoners.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: The repatriation of American prisoners in Vietnam began this morning with the ceremonial turnover at Hanoi's Gia Lam airport of three planeloads of men. The first of three Air Force medical jets arrived two hours behind schedule because of early morning rain and ground fog in Hanoi. Prisoners began boarding the plane after a ceremony at the airfield. [Page 1, Colunin 8.]

headline: Frazier, Unitas and Such Give Extra Attention to Certain Fans
lead_paragraph: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, and Johnny Unitas, the quarterback, have called them up with personal greetings at Christmaslime. Jerry Lucas, the Knicks's forward, is preparing a magic show for them. Ron Swoboda of the Yankees is going to have them at the Stadium this spring.
author: By Grace Lichtenstein

headline: Long Wait Is Ended for 27, Set Free in South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 13 — After 12 hours of debate and anguishing delay, 27 American prisoners of war held in South Vietnam were freed last night by the Vietcong, flown to Saigon and then rushed to Clark Air Base in the Philippines.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Hijacker, 22, Who Surrendered Gets 30‐Year Prison Sentence
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12—Francis M. Goodell, 22 years old, of Manassas, Va., Vietnam war veteran who hijacked an airliner with 58 persons aboard last July, was sentenced today to 30 years in prison.

headline: Vietcong Say Saigon and U.S. Repeatedly Violate Cease‐Fire
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 12 (UPI) — The Vietcong side accused South Vietnam and the United States today of repeated violations of the Vietnam peace agreement and warped that it “will not go on tolerating” them.

headline: Scholarships for Veterans
lead_paragraph: Twenty scholarships of $1,000 a year each will be offered to Vietnam veterans enrolling next fall in the New York University General Studies program, the school's director of financial aid, Raymond J. Brienza, announced yesterday. Combat veterans will be given priority. The regular tuition fee is $2,700 a year.

headline: First Prisoner Release Is Completed
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Tuesday, Feb. 13 — The first released American prisoners of the Vietnam war were greeted with cheers of welcome and tears of joy here yesterday as they stepped off military evacuation jets. They looked in better physical condition than most onlookers had expected, and the hospital commander here pronounced their general health “reasonably good.”
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Home Again
lead_paragraph: They are strong men, as President Nixon said after watching the first planeloads of Vietnam war prisoners return to American hands. In the understated words of Navy Capt. Jeremiah A. Denton, they were called to “serve our country under difficult circumstances”—indeed, among the most difficult this Republic has demanded of its sons.

headline: Release of Prisoners in Hanoi Is Simple and Swift
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 12 (Agence FrancePresse)—Buses still bearing the camouflage paint of war arrived at the civilian airport at Gia Lam this morning carrying American prisoners of war in their last moments of captivity.

headline: U.S. HEADQUARTERS MOVING TO THAILAND
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) —The Pentagon announced today that it was setting up a new Southeast Asian headquarters at a base in Thailand to control teams searching for missing United States servicemen and to direct any air activity after March 28.

headline: P.O. W. Became Pawn In a Complex Struggle
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12—With the first release today of American prisoners in Vietnam, Washington and Hanoi began the final act of a lengthy drama in which the prisoners became pawns in a political and military struggle.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: First Prisoner Release Completed
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Tuesday, Feb. 13 — The first released American prisoners of the Vietnam war were greeted with cheers of welcome and tears of joy here yesterday as they stepped off military evacuation jets. They looked in better physical condition than most onlookers had expected, and the hospital commander here pronounced their general health “reasonably good.”
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Bao Dai Bids for Return To Vietnam as Arbiter
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Feb. 12—A voice out of Vietnam's past was heard here today as the exiled emperor, Bao Dai, made a bid to return to his homeland as a “national arbiter.”

headline: Long Wait Is Ended for 27, Set Free in South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 13 — After 12 hours of debate and anguishing delay, 27 American prisoners of war held in South Vietnam were freed last night by the Vietcong, flown to Saigon and then rushed to Clark Air Base in the Philippines.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnamese Prisoners joyous on Return
lead_paragraph: BIEN HOA, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 13—The first 140 South Vietnamese prisoners of war released by the Communists joyously stepped off American transport planes here shortly after sundown yesterday.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Happy Hubbub Envelops Homes as Families Await Their P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: “I was so tickled to see my son get off the plane, I just sat at that television like I was glued there.”
author: By Lawrence Van Gelder

headline: What Keeps Released Manin Saigon?
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 14—Why did Richard G. Waldhaus stay in Vietnam Monday when the 142 other American prisoners freed by the Communists flew to Clark Air Base in the, Philippines?
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐Prisoners Rushing for Gifts, Ice Cream and Home
lead_paragraph: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Wednesday, Feb. 14 —The first two returned war prisoners departed for the United States last night and another planeload of about 20 were scheduled to leave for home today. Meanwhile the men who were released by the Vietnamese Communists on Monday were treated to beer, banana splits, a movie and a shopping trip to the base exchange.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: The White House Press Office is now able to speak fluently in six languages, all from the tongue of Andrew T. Falkiewicz, who was born 43 years ago in Poland and has been working for, the United States Information Agency for 17 years. Mr. Falkiewicz, a United‐States citizen since 1954, speaks English, Polish, Czech, German, French and Russian fluently. His White House duties, which he assumed last month, include dealing with the 1,000 foreign correspondents‐300 of them in Washington—who work in this country. His salary is about $30,000 a year. He was said to have been “discovered” by Ronald L. Zeigler, the White House Press Secretary, while working at the American Embassy in Moscow during President Nixon's visit there last year.

headline: Who Buys Time For Whom?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—This has become a kind of Middle East period for the White House. King Hussein of Jordan visited President Nixon last week to stress that, with the Vietnam war over and both Moscow and Peking playing up to Washington, it is time for a fresh United States initiative. And Israel's Goida Meir arrives in just over a fortnight.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Hanoi, in a Surprise Move, To Free 20 in a Few Days
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13—North Vietnam, in what appears to be a goodwill gesture, has agreed to release 20 more American prisoners of war within the next few days, the Pentagon announced today. The decision to release the prisoners ahead of schedule was linked by a Pentagon spokesman to Henry A. Kissinger's visit to Hanoi over the weekend.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: FLAG AT FULL STAFF TODAY FOR CAPTIVES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) —President Nixon ordered today that all flags be raised to full staff tomorrow to honor returning prisoners of war and American casualties in Vietnam.

headline: VIETNAMESE SIDES TRADE PRISONERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 14—The Saigon Government and the Communists exchanged 1,021 more prisoners of war yesterday on a battered metal airstrip in the little town of Loc Ninh, 77 miles north of here.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐Prisoners Rushing for Gifts Ice Cream and Home
